You are here:  DH home  -   Policy and guidance  -   Health and social care topics  -   Healthcare associated infection  -   Healthcare associated infection key documents  -  Healthcare acquired general article



		

		
	
		
		

		
			
		
				
				
					
					
	                


A plan for action



Towards cleaner hospitals and lower rates of infection and Winning ways are two key policy documents that set out a strategy to improve hospital cleanliness and tackle hospital acquired infections.


Towards cleaner hospitals and lower rates of infection















Empowering patients and being open with the public are top of the agenda



















Towards cleaner hospitals sets out an action plan based on work already underway.


Empowering patients and being open with the public are top of the agenda. Patients will be encouraged to feel able to check NHS staff have washed their hands. Patient forums will be invited to inspect four times a year, and rates of MRSA will be made easily available to everyone.

In the NHS, a Matron's Charter is being developed to strengthen cleaning teams and ensure patients' views are heard. Nurses will also receive checklists to help them assess compliance with hygiene and decontamination policies.

Independent inspection will track progress, as cleanliness contributes to the Healthcare Commission's annual star ratings. Cleanliness and infection control are also included in the new National Healthcare Standards to be monitored by the Healthcare Commission.

Towards cleaner hospitals also puts MRSA at the forefront of research and learning in the NHS. Summits later in 2004 will gather together international healthcare professionals to discuss infection control.

 Towards cleaner hospitals and lower rates of infection: A summary of action





Winning ways




The Chief Medical Officer's (CMO's) report Winning ways sets out key issues and detailed guidance in seven action areas to reduce healthcare associated infection. They are:



    
        	active surveillance and investigation
	reducing the infection risk from use of catheters, tubes, cannulae, instruments and other devices
	reducing reservoirs of infection
	high standards of hygiene in clinical practice
	prudent use of antibiotics
	management and organisation
	research and development.





    


 Winning ways: working together to reduce healthcare associated infection in England

		HMS Mersey
		News
		09 Nov 04

				
	


								

				

								

			
					
					
					
	09 Nov 04


St Malo

After so many visits of the United Kingdom Mersey was lucky enough to get her first foreign visit.  The ship was alongside for the celebrations of the Entende Cordiale, an agreement of friendship between the United Kingdom and France.  While in the small picturesque town we joined the French Frigate the FS Germinal. HMS Mersey held a reception onboard where the night was enjoyed by all that attended.  This provided a great opportunity for both Navies to bond and learn about each other.  Both ships were open to visitors, which was well received by the local population.  Not only constrained to St Malo the local Anglican Church in Dinard the Eglise Anglicane de Dinard, invited an attendance at their Sunday Service where the Commanding Officer and others attended. The ship set sail leaving behind a beautiful town and some fond memories.



Chief of Staff Warfare to Cincfleet

On 5th October Rear Admiral D G Snelson CB Chief of Staff Warfare to CinCFleet visited the ship.  This allowed the Admiral to gain a true insight into how a River class works and the feeling from the people who work on it.  The sailors provide the Admiral with a good insight into Mersey and how they make her work.  The visit was received well by all parties involved.



Guernsey

Recently the ship underwent some operational continuity training with HMS Severn. With a tendency for skill fade both ships pulled out and performed well.  The training went on for a week with both ships pulling into Guernsey on completion for some down time.  This was a welcome break for the sailors as they had not only been working hard to achieve the correct standards but the weather was not kind either, with strong winds, poor visibility and rough seas all a gentle reminder to what winter can bring.   The ships visit provided a Royal Navy presence at the Charybdis/Limborne commemoration weekend where the surviving members of these war time vessels were hosted onboard Mersey for an evening reception.  During the visit the football teams of Severn and Mersey played a friendly match with squadron rivalry at stake both teams played for the win but after a lucky break from Severn the match concluded with a six – two defeat to Mersey.



Grimsby

The ship recently pulled into Grimsby to aid with the Fishery enforcement Officers Course that spends a week of the course in Grimsby.  This allowed a gentle break in the patrol cycle for the sailors to enjoy a night ashore.  The visit was only for 24 hours.



Hull

With East Coast ports top of the agenda for our current patrol area Mersey was pleased to visit Hull for a patrol standoff.  Able to enjoy two and half days of shore time the Ships Company took no time at all in making the most of the delights that hull has to offer.



04 Nov 04

Nearing the later part of the year and HMS Mersey has seen a successful year in her role as a Fisheries Protection Vessel.  From her performance during OST in the Spring when she went operational to October when she went through continuity training with her sister ship Severn.  The ship is now in Portsmouth for most of November when she will conduct two more patrols of the UK before the ship goes on a well-deserved Christmas leave.  From all serving on HMS Mersey we wish you a pleasant Christmas and a Happy New Year.

								Tim Wright - trAce's Digital Writer-in-Residence asks: is blogging fertile ground for new forms of digital storytelling? more . . .
 
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
				           
								
									
									
														
							


				
		
					
								
								
								
									
								
							
	
									?	Reply	???	Quote	???	Top	???	Bottom	???	?


							


				


		
		
		

		
	

	
			
		
		
		
	
		
			
					
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
							
												
					

					
						

					
					

					
	

					Kate Pullinger

					
					

					Posts: 111

					Joined: Sep 2002
					
					
					
					
				
	
						
								
								
								
	



								
								Tuesday January 27, 2004 2:44 PM
								
									
										
									
																
								
		
			
			
				
			
			
			
				
					
			
			
		



	
								
								

								
									
								
								Really interesting article by Tim about blogging.  Raises lots of interesting issues and points.  I have a student who is in the process of writing a fictional blog but he does have a double agenda for it - he's using it to give another life to a character in a screenplay he's written and is hoping to produce, and he's also hoping to promote a particular health issue lobby through it (I guess that's a triple agenda).  But I think the idea of over-lapping forms, each with a different agenda, is potentially very fruitful.



I liked the way that in the early days of Salaam Pax a lot of the discussion around his blog was whether or not he was 'real'.  In many ways, it was great that it turned out that he was 'real', because his insights into the war in Iraq have been so revealing.  But at the same time I find it kind of... what, baffling?  that if it had turned out to be 'not real', i.e. fiction, it would have also been 'inauthentic'.  Hmm.



Kate 
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
									
										
									
									

-------------------------

									www.katepullinger.com
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
				           
								
									
									
														
							


				
		
					
								
								
								
									
								
							
	
									?	Reply	???	Quote	???	Top	???	Bottom	???	?


							


				


		
		
		

		
	

	
			
		
		
		
	
		
			
					
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
							
												
					

					
						

					
					

					
	

					Tim Wright

					
					

					Posts: 394

					Joined: Jul 2003
					
					
					
					
				
	
						
								
								
								
	



								
								Thursday January 29, 2004 11:49 AM
								
									
										
									
																
								
		
			
			
				
			
			
			
				
					
			
			
		



	
								
								

								
									
								
								Thanks for your comments Kate. I think this business about authenticity is fascinating. I've got 'Everything Is Illuminated' by Jonathan Safran Foer sitting by my bed, and I'm told that the author writes compellingly about the Ukraine without ever having been there. 



There is a cult for 'research' and factual accuracy amongst writers of fiction that (I think) comes from the fact that most writers these days have some kind of background in journalism. As I mention in my article, there a lot of journalists within the blogging community too.



There are some quite interesting threads in Grand Text Auto about the possible 'fusion' of fiction and reality in the online environment.



Cheers



timw 
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
									
										
									
									

-------------------------

									Tim Wright
Digital Writer In Residence
InResidence Weblog
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
				           
								
									
									
														
							


				
		
					
								
								
								
									
								
							
	
									?	Reply	???	Quote	???	Top	???	Bottom	???	?


							


				


		
		
		

		
	

	
			
		
		
		
	
		
			
					
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
							
												
					

					
						

					
					

					
	

					Tim Wright

					
					

					Posts: 394

					Joined: Jul 2003
					
					
					
					
				
	
						
								
								
								
	



								
								Monday February 02, 2004 10:33 AM
								
									
										
									
																
								
		
			
			
				
			
			
			
				
					
			
			
		



	
								
								

								
									
								
								Interesting development this w/e. 



I have been contacted by the author of She's a Flight Risk pointing out errors in my article on Blog Fiction:



You wrote: "She's A Flight Risk, for example, is by an author who purports to be on the run around the globe funded by various online share deals. But from the very beginning there is no serious attempt to make us believe in this person. Yes, there is intrigue and entertainment to be gleaned from her situation, but her personality is left underwritten. And it's absolutely not critical for the reader to know or even wonder whether this person is real or not."



Well, if this is your writing then it is pretty clear that you haven't bothered to read my diaries (even if you are quite happy to critique them).  "...funded by various online share deals..." ?  What ever does that mean?  Or do I even want to know?  Certainly it bears no resemblance to anything I've ever written.



As for failing to make attempts to have people "believe" me- that's not why I write.  To have people "believe."  Sure, it is nice if someone makes a real connection on occasion, but it's bonus material, not the goal.



I do so love how various reviewers constantly call my work "fiction" without even so much as a "by your leave..." or bothering to contact me to ask e.g., for an interview.



Bah.  At least John Richardson did. http://www.esquire.com/features/articles/2003/030922_mfe_isabella_1.html



-isa 
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
									
										
									
									

-------------------------

									Tim Wright
Digital Writer In Residence
InResidence Weblog
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
				           
								
									
									
														
							


				
		
					
								
								
								
									
								
							
	
									?	Reply	???	Quote	???	Top	???	Bottom	???	?


							


				


		
		
		

		
	

	
			
		
		
		
	
		
			
					
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
							
												
					

					
						

					
					

					
	

					Tim Wright

					
					

					Posts: 394

					Joined: Jul 2003
					
					
					
					
				
	
						
								
								
								
	



								
								Monday February 02, 2004 10:36 AM
								
									
										
									
																
								
		
			
			
				
			
			
			
				
					
			
			
		



	
								
								

								
									
								
								Here is my reply:



Hi



Thanks for you email. I'm sorry that my potted summary of your work annoyed you. I agree that that the reference to 'online share deals' is a misrepresentation of how you claim to finance your 'flight' and I'm happy to publish a correction in the trAce forum.



The error came from trying to condense a description of your site into one paragraph and I'm sorry that by doing so I misrepresented your story. I can assure you I have read quite a lot of your blog and there are references there to your use of initial funds to invest and speculate via a money manager:



"Busy beyond belief. So much for my portfolio's war gains. They weren't all wiped out, but it was looking like a nice little bump on Friday and looks like a smaller bump today."



"Talked to money managers, may have picked one and a strategy for investing."



"Fine, then we'll give you a break. If you start making big returns on this portfolio we might have to reconsider. This is a lot of risk for me and I have to spend more with your portfolio since it's so large." 



You do also admit that you are deliberately vague about your finances, leaving your readers free to speculate about where your money comes from. So I guess there's some small excuse there for my error. I hope you can forgive me anyway. I'm not some hard-arsed journo rushing to judge you. I'm just another writer on the web trying to make sense of what I find.



On the issue of whether your work is fiction, or whether you are a 'real' person, I wasn't saying it was important for people to 'believe' in you. In fact, I suspect we rather agree about how this online storytelling malarkey might work. As you write yourself:



"I suppose from my perspective I don't really care what people think. If I say it's not fiction, then that's just part of the hoax. If I say it is, I'm just covering up to stay safe (both of these possibilities have been suggested). If I don't give details it's because this is an elaborate ruse. If I do then I'm an idiot for being so reckless (though this entire post-it-to-the-web endeavor is reckless). I can't keep everyone happy, so I'll just write- as I have been. As for you, I don't know. Just read? Love, hate, enjoy, despise... whatever suits your fancy."



There is therefore no obligation on my part to somehow 'check' whether your story is fiction or not (is there?). That's why your blog is so fascinating to me. It lives in the hinterland between our 'real' selves and our imaginative selves - and it's often the space where good examples of digital (or interactive) literature can be found.



I am of course intrigued by the idea that there is now an interaction between the writer (you) and the reader (me) that is happening outside the blog itself. (And I notice BTW that you had some difficulty with how the 'comment' function/reader interaction can disrupt the storyteller's flow - or were you simply playing with that idea?)



I guess this brief exchange DOES change how 'believable' I take you to be. But it doesn't prove anything (does it?) about whether your story is a work of fiction or not. And I'm not sure the Esquire article gets any further than I have in unravelling that question.



Thanks for getting in touch. I will post a correction tomorrow in the forum. Feel free to sign up at http://www.trace.ntu.ac.uk/forums/ and give me a hard time if you feel it's still required.



Cheers



Tim Wright

 
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
									
										
									
									

-------------------------

									Tim Wright
Digital Writer In Residence
InResidence Weblog
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
				           
								
									
									
														
							


				
		
					
								
								
								
									
								
							
	
									?	Reply	???	Quote	???	Top	???	Bottom	???	?


							


				


		
		
		

		
	

	
			
		
		
		
	
		
			
					
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
							
												
					

					
						

					
					

					
	

					Tim Wright

					
					

					Posts: 394

					Joined: Jul 2003
					
					
					
					
				
	
						
								
								
								
	



								
								Monday February 02, 2004 10:39 AM
								
									
										
									
																
								
		
			
			
				
			
			
			
				
					
			
			
		



	
								
								

								
									
								
								And here's Flight Risk author (isa) coming back one more time:



>Hi



Hi.



>Thanks for you email. I'm sorry that my potted summary of your work 

>annoyed you.



I get overly cranky.  Best to ignore me till I go away in those circumstances.



>I agree that that the reference to 'online share deals' is a 

>misrepresentation of how you claim to finance your 'flight' and I'm 

>happy to publish a correction in the trAce forum.



The only reason I talked to money managers at all was for capital preservation and because I had attorneys who told me it was absolutely critical to get the assets under professional management.  At first I babbled about this online because it was new to me.  That was a mistake.



As for your summary, I just didn't want to be cast as stealing from widows and orphans or something.  "Online share deals" is just slightly north of "internet porn baroness."



>You do also admit that you are deliberately vague about your finances,





So stipulated.



>leaving your readers free to speculate about where your money comes 

>from.



Certain legal issues mandate that, I'm afraid.



>So I guess there's some small excuse there for my error. I hope you can 

>forgive me anyway.



Yes yes.  Done.



>I'm not some hard-arsed journo rushing to judge you.



I am wary of those.  Sorry.  My antenna are up this weekend.



>In fact, I suspect we rather agree about how this online storytelling 

>malarkey might work. As you write yourself: There is therefore no 

>obligation on my part to somehow 'check' whether your story is fiction 

>or not (is there?). That's why your blog is so fascinating to me. It 

>lives in the hinterland between our 'real' selves and

>our imaginative selves - and it's often the space where

>good examples of digital (or interactive) literature can be found.



Again, I was just cranky and tired of dealing with so many nasty emails and postings.  Yours got lumped in with the rest.  Sorry.



>I am of course intrigued by the idea that there is now an interaction 

>between the writer (you) and the reader (me) that is happening outside 

>the blog itself. (And I notice BTW that you had some difficulty with 

>how the 'comment' function/reader interaction can disrupt the 

>>storyteller's

flow - or were you simply playing with that idea?)



I put comments up concerned right off the bat that it was a mistake.  I stuck with it for a long time- as long as I could.  Then I just got tired of being called a "c**t"  (Excuse me.  I do so hate that word even in type but it gets the point across) and being the "host" to the parasites that felt they were owed a public forum to vent their nastiness.  When Moveable Type 3.0 comes out with registration for comments I will likely put them back up.



>And I'm not sure the Esquire article gets any further

>than I have in unravelling that question.



John and I had a very strict understanding about what could be printed and what couldn't.  He wouldn't let me at raw copy per se (he is a journalist) but we agreed ahead of time that many things were off-limits and could not show up in print.  That included any specifics about my identity or anything that might reveal where I was.  That's a lot of detail that had to be yanked.  John insisted on some rather substantial documentation before we spoke, however.  He didn't want to go on record unless he himself was satisfied.  He and my agent talked for weeks before it got set up properly because of the specific concerns I had/have.  That is the first,  and last time I will do that.



>Thanks for getting in touch. I will post a correction tomorrow in the 

>forum. Feel free to sign up at http://www.trace.ntu.ac.uk/forums/ and 

>give me a

>hard time if you feel it's still required.



Signing up would link me to an IP.  :)  I use a pretty safe proxy in the U.S. but that's still asking for trouble, signing up.  :)



- isa

 
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
									
										
									
									

-------------------------

									Tim Wright
Digital Writer In Residence
InResidence Weblog
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
				           
								
									
									
														
							


				
		
					
								
								
								
									
								
							
	
									?	Reply	???	Quote	???	Top	???	Bottom	???	?


							


				


		
		
		

		
	

	
			
		
		
		
	
		
			
					
					
					
					
					
					
					
						
							
												
					

					
						

					
					

					
	

					Trailer Star

					
					

					Posts: 15

title: Royal Navy: The Great 'Shaft Line Lotto'
text:
Royal Navy: The Great 'Shaft Line Lotto'




		
			
			
					Tue 23 Nov 2004	
				


			
			
			

		

						
					
									 Surface Fleet
	 Fleet Air Arm
	 Submarine Service
	 Royal Marines
	 Royal Fleet Auxiliary
	 Royal Naval Reserve
	 Royal Marines Reserve
	 Establishments

	
			

							
	
					
									 News and Events
	 Royal Navy Careers
	 Royal Marines Careers
	 The RN Today
	 Navy Life
	 Interactive Features
	 Picture Gallery

	
			

							
		



		
					 
				
 				 	 
				
					
				


				
				You are in:

					
	
					Surface Fleet
		Type 23 Frigates
		HMS Kent
		Charities
		The Great 'Shaft Line Lotto'

				
	


								

				

								

			
					
					
					
	
The Great ‘Shaft Line Lotto’




Earlier this year, to provide a regular contribution to the Ships Charity Chest, and some light entertainment for the Ship’s Company, the Marine Engineer Department of HMS Kent established the game of ‘Shaft Line Lotto’.  The game is now played every time the Ship comes alongside in port and contributes a considerable income for the Ship’s principle charity, Demelza House childrens’ hospice in the County of Kent.



The game is a cross between Bingo and Roulette.  Both shafts are painted with numbers from 0 to 9 around their rim.  Arrows attached to a fixed point above the shaft are then used to determine the winning numbers as the shaft comes to rest.  Reading the numbers on both shafts naturally generates a random figure between 00 and 99.



Numbers are sold from the Ship’s Control Centre the night before entering a port and all members of the Ship’s Company have the opportunity to purchase a number for the price of one English Pound. The Captain, Commander Simon Hardern, has a standing number 4 (the age of his son - for the next the eight months at least).  If they have been lucky enough to pick the number indicted by the shafts then they receive half of the monies collected, with the other half being donated to Charity.



Whilst manoeuvring alongside a berth, shafts may be stopped several times.  However, winning numbers are never read until the order “Finished With Main Engines” has been passed from the Bridge.  Chief Petty Officer Mick Bland, the Head of the Propulsion Section on board, then has the honour of reading the numbers and passing them to the Marine Engineer Officer, Lieutenant Commander Ned Kelly, who declares the winner from the list of numbers purchased.



It is normal for all 100 numbers to be sold and there have been winners in every Department on board - apart from the Captain that is - despite him doing all the hard work of bringing the Ship alongside!  This activity has generated over £300 in the two months since it started, and looks set to provide a continued source of entertainment, and charitable income, for some time to come.

title: Royal Navy: History
text:
Royal Navy: History




		
			
			
					Tue 23 Nov 2004	
				


			
			
			

		

						
					
									 Surface Fleet
	 Fleet Air Arm
	 Submarine Service
	 Royal Marines
	 Royal Fleet Auxiliary
	 Royal Naval Reserve
	 Royal Marines Reserve
	 Establishments

	
			

							
	
					
									 News and Events
	 Royal Navy Careers
	 Royal Marines Careers
	 The RN Today
	 Navy Life
	 Interactive Features
	 Picture Gallery

	
			

							
		



		
					 
				
 				 	 
				
					
				


				
				You are in:

					
	
					Fleet Air Arm
		Naval Air Squadrons
		820
		History

				
	


								

				

								

			
					
					
					
	History




820 Squadron formed in April 1933 when the FaireyIIIF aircraft of 450 Flight Royal Air Force were transferred to the Fleet Air Arm. The Squadron was initially attached to the Carrier HMS Courageous for Spotter-Reconnaissance duties. The Squadron re-equipped in turn with Fairey Seals and Blackburn Sharks before receiving the Fairey Swordfish in the autumn of 1937. The Squadron embarked in HMS Ark Royal in November 1938 and continued operating her Swordfish from there for the next three years.



Shortly after the beginning of the Second World War it became clear that the Carriers were too vulnerable to operate their aircraft solely in the anti-submarine role and so the Squadron was re-tasked to undertake the roles of surface search and torpedo-attack.     Ark Royal, with 820 embarked, spent the first half of 1940 in the Atlantic on convoy protection duties before going north in support of the Narvik operation.  In June they moved to the Mediterranean operating against both the French and Italian fleets and escorting convoys to and from Malta.



820 Squadron played a prominent part in the search for, and destruction of, the German battleship Bismarck. The ship's steering gear was disabled by torpedoes delivered by Squadron aircraft; thus allowing our surface forces to intercept, engage and sink her. Later in 1941 the Squadron was re-equipped with Fairey Albacores and early in 1942 embarked in HMS Formidable for service in the Indian Ocean. In November 1942, 820 aircraft supported the Allied landings in North Africa and in 1943 operated in support of the landings in Sicily and Salerno. Later in November 1943 the Squadron sank a U-boat operating in the Mediterranean. 



On return to the UK in early 1944, 820 embarked in HMS Idefatigable with 12 new Barracuda aircraft and sailed for Norway where the Squadron took part in the attacks against the Tirpitz. Towards the end of the year the Squadron again re-equipped, this time with Grumman Avengers, and re-embarked in Indefatigable to sail for the Far East. In early 1946 the Squadron returned home and in March they disbanded. 



In July 1951 the Squadron re-formed equipped with the Fairey Firefly V flying again in the anti-submarine role. During 1952 and 1953, 820 embarked in turn in HMS Indomitable and HMS Theseus and spent considerable time exercising in the Mediterranean. After subsequent re-conversion to the Grumman Avenger and then to the Fairey Gannet MK1 the Squadron operated during 1954 to 1956 with both HMS Centaur and HMS Bulwark. 820 were again disbanded on 2 December 1957 only to re-form on the same day at HMS Vernon; this time as a Helicopter Squadron equipped with the Westland Whirlwind MK VII. The Squadron embarked in HMS Hermes in May 1958 flying in the anti-submarine and commando role and remained there until October 1960 when the Squadron was again disbanded.

 

Re-formed in 1964 with the Westland Wessex MK1, 820 became HMS Eagle's anti-submarine squadron. After five years the Wessex MK1 was replaced by the MK3, the first autonomous equipped anti-submarine helicopter in the Royal Navy. 



In 1969 the Squadron transferred to the Tiger Class Helicopter Cruiser HMS Blake and remained with her until the ship was sent for disposal in 1979. The Wessex were replaced by the superior Westland Sea King MK1 in December 1972 and these were in turn replaced by the MK2 and in December 1980 by the Sea King MK5. 



In April 1982 the Squadron embarked in HMS Invincible and sailed for the South Atlantic and the subsequent Falklands war. During the conflict the Squadron successfully flew over 4700 hours in a variety of roles. HMS Invincible spent 166 days continuously at sea during this time, a world record for continuous Carrier operations. 

Since its return from the South Atlantic the Squadron has been involved in exercises with ships and aircraft of other NATO countries. At the end of 1985 the Squadron ended its connection with HMS Invincible and formed part of the Air Group on board HMS Ark Royal. 



In February 1990 the Squadron took delivery of the much improved, Sea King MK6 with its integrated Sonar systems. In January 1993, the Squadron was recalled from leave and sent, at short notice, to support the British contingent of UN forces in Bosnia (Operation Grapple); embarking in the Royal Fleet Auxiliary ships Fort Grange and Olwen. The Primary Role of the Squadron switched to logistical support, ferrying men and supplies around the Adriatic. During the deployment, Squadron aircraft carried out in excess of 1,400 deck landings and flew over 1,900 hours in support of the task. 



In 1994 the Squadron was once again deployed to the Adriatic in support of the continuing Operations in Bosnia; this time embarked in HMS Ark Royal. The Squadron's role continued to be that of logistical support with an intense schedule of numerous stores deliveries, personnel transfers and supply operations. On return to the UK, and with the de-commissioning of Ark Royal, the Squadron re-deployed on to HMS Illustrious. 1996 saw the Squadron in the eastern Atlantic taking part in major exercises followed by visits to America. In early 1997 they embarked, once again in Illustrious for a round the world deployment as part of Ocean Wave 97. 



A trip to the Gulf, in support of Operation Bolton, started off 1998, which ended with the Squadron returning to its base in Cornwall whilst HMS Illustrious underwent a major refit including the removal of her Sea Dart missile system in order to increase the deck space for aircraft operations. Far from being unemployed, 820 Squadron conducted further valuable Anti-Submarine Warfare Training embarked in Royal Fleet Auxiliaries Fort Victoria, Fort George, Olwen and Olna as well as the Dutch ship Amsterdam. Two aircraft were also detached to the underwater ranges in the Bahamas for weapon trials. 1999 saw the Squadron re-embarked on HMS Illustrious participating in various exercises both in UK waters and further afield.  During operational patrols in the Gulf in 2000 the Squadron was re-tasked to provide humanitarian aid in Mozambique and for Operation Palliser in Sierra Leone. 



Upto the end of 2003, another extremely busy year for 820 NAS, a look back over the previous 12 months demonstrates the varied and intensive activity undertaken by a modern Front line ASW Squadron.



The planned reprofiling of 820 NAS from Sea King Mk VI to Merlin HM Mk I on 1 January 2002 was postponed for a total of 9 months due to the uncertain military requirement post 11 September 2001.  The Sea King element of the Squadron contributed to Operation Telic in the Arabian Gulf, primarily in the Support Helicopter role embarked in RFAs Argus and Fort Austin and subsequently in HMS Ark Royal.  



Back in the UK, throughout this period, a small Merlin Formation Cell maintained the Fleet focus on aircraft update for 820 NAS, providing Merlin aircraft support to HMS Invincible as she emerged from a lengthy refit period, having received the enhancements required to embark and sustain deployed Merlins.  This dual aircraft type operation was facilitated by operating Merlins under the Flight Safety and Air Engineering umbrella of 824 NAS, necessary prior to achieving the independent operations clearance attained by Performance Assessment and Rededication programmed for late 2003.



A total of four embarked periods were completed by the Merlin contingent, culminating in the Operational Readiness Inspection for Invincible as she progressed towards Fleet Flag Ship and Ready Carrier status, where Merlin capability and versatility was a key enabler.



The completion of Sea King operations Post Telic and the aircraft type ‘reprofiling’ to Merlin was marked in style with a Sea King farewell ‘fly-by’ followed by a formal evening dinner attended by past, present and future Squadron members, spanning several decades of Squadron history.



After Summer Leave, the formal standing-up of 820 NAS as a Merlin Squadron took place on 1 September 2003, with the initial focus centring on personnel joining and induction, as well as ensuring squadron infrastructure was fully compliant with Merlin operations.



A very successful detachment to Kiel was conducted during November, where close liaison and co-operation with the German submarine U-Boat ‘U25’ greatly enhanced the Squadron’s primary role capability and forged good relationships for future training opportunities.



The final focus for the year was to successfully achieve independent operations status by completing the Squadron Performance Assessment, which was followed by the Squadron Rededication ceremony on 5 December.  



During February 2004 the Squadron embarked in RFA Fort George, providing the ASW and ASuW assets required for JMC 041.  This was the final workup exercise prior to 820 NAS assuming R2 front-line Squadron status.



The Squadron looks forward to Easter leave which is followed by embarkation in RFA Fort George for Aurora 2004 and operation Rapid Alliance, which will take place in America returning mid July before Summer leave.

title: Royal Navy: United Kingdom Hydrographic Office
text:
Royal Navy: United Kingdom Hydrographic Office




		
			
			
					Tue 16 Nov 2004	
				


			
			
			

		

						
					
									 Surface Fleet
	 Fleet Air Arm
	 Submarine Service
	 Royal Marines
	 Royal Fleet Auxiliary

	 Royal Marines Reserve

				You are in:

					
	
					Surface Fleet
		Hydrographic Vessels
		HMS Endurance
		United Kingdom Hydrographic Office

				
	


								

				

								

			
					
					
					
	Charting the Falklands, South Georgia and the Antarctic



By Stuart Osbourne (UKHO)




The United Kingdom Hydrographic Office (UKHO) is based in Taunton, Somerset and employs approximately 950 people and one of its main objectives is to provide worldwide navigational chart coverage for both military and merchant shipping.  Each chart assists the mariner by graphically representing the following:






	The depth of water from the sea surface to ocean floor



	Tidal information to allow the mariner to adjust the depths to the state of the tide.



	Dangerous underwater obstructions such as wrecks, cables and pipelines.



	Position of the coastline or ice fronts.



	Positional information in the form of a grid and magnetic compass.  The former allows the mariner to plot the ships current position by latitude and longitude, and the latter allows the mariner to plot the ships direction and course.



	Navigational aids such as lighthouses, beacons and buoys.  The chart provides the position of these structures (relative to the aforementioned grid), the light and radar emitting characteristics, colour, shape and where available their name.



	Anchorage areas, restricted areas and traffic separation schemes.



	Topographic information that would be a useful reference to the mariner.  Examples would include church spires, radio masts, vertical cliff faces and heights of coastal hills and mountains.




One of the roles at the UKHO is as a cartographer maintaining the existing chart coverage, and producing new chart coverage, of the Falklands Islands, South Georgia and the Antarctic Peninsula.



Due to its outstanding natural beauty, remoteness and its abundance of wildlife the southern ocean, its islands and the Antarctic continent have become the subject of increased levels of tourism over recent years.  The tourists travel to these areas by an ever increasing number of cruise ships, some of which have the capability to carry upwards of 1000 passengers.  With the combination of the amount of vessel traffic, limited rescue facilities and the fragile nature of the environment it is imperative that the navigational charts of the area aids safe and informed navigation.



Each year the RN and the UKHO decide on which geographical areas require surveying during the following season.  This is usually decided by looking at recent tourism statistics collated by the International Association of Antarctic Tour Operators (IAATO), the work of the British Antarctic Survey (BAS) and defence / FCO requirements.  Once an area to be surveyed has been decided upon HMS Endurance is issued with a ‘Hydrographic Instruction’ which sets out the geographical limits of the survey and details on how the area should be surveyed.



HMS Endurance is equipped with a single beam echo sounder, as are her two small motor boats the James Caird and the Nimrod.  When surveying HMS Endurance undertakes the deep water surveying, while the two smaller boats survey the bays and harbours.  This provides me at the UKHO with one of my only sources of large areas of accurate depth information in the Southern Ocean.  In addition to her survey capabilities HMS Endurance carries 2 lynx helicopters which are equipped with cameras to allow them to take vertical aerial photographs of the coastline and offshore islands.



Towards the end of the season all this information is sent in digital format to the UKHO where it is processed and analysed.  Both the survey work and the aerial photographs are compared against what is currently shown on the published navigational chart.  More often than not, this reveals certain differences that the mariner should be made aware of.  The UKHO has various ways of providing the mariner with this information.  Firstly, if the survey has revealed something of a very serious nature it will be issued as a Radio Navigational Warning.  This is a radio message that can be sent to vessels in the area of the danger alerting them to it immediately.  Secondly, less serious dangers are issued as Notice to Mariners every week by the UKHO, both in paper format as well as on our website www.UKHO.gov.uk.  Finally the survey information is included in either a new edition of an existing chart, or alternatively an entirely new chart is generated.



This current season HMS Endurance has carried out some valuable survey work and aerial photography around South Georgia and the Antarctic Peninsula which will enhance the existing chart coverage of the area.  Due to my work at the UKHO I have been lucky enough to be invited on board HMS Endurance for her final work period down towards Halley Research base in the Weddell Sea to the east of the Antarctic Peninsula.  This provides me with a unique opportunity to experience the work of a large survey vessel ‘at the sharp end’,  helping to process the data that she has collected, which I will eventually include on the charts when I return to Taunton.  Another valuable experience that I have gained is being able to witness the navigational charts in use up on the ship’s bridge, and the reliability that is placed upon them.



The main task of this work period was to liaise with the BAS supply vessel RRS Ernest Shackleton and create a temporary aviation fuel depot site on the Antarctic mainland, from where the BAS fixed wing aircraft could move the fuel onto various permanent Antarctic bases around the continent.  HMS Endurance supplied her two lynx helicopters for the operation enabling the movement of the barrels from RRS Ernest Shackleton to the temporary ‘skiway’ on the mainland.  I was invited to be part of the shore party on the first day of the depot laying.  I was flown ashore by helicopter and joined the permanent shore party where our task was to unload the barrels from the helicopters under slung carrying net, and to assist with the transfer of the fuel barrels to the BAS temporary skiway and ultimately on board their Twin Otter aircraft.  This proved quite a demanding task in temperatures of -15C combined with the weight of the barrels and the soft underfoot conditions, but it was a most unique and enjoyable experience nonetheless.



Now that the main task of the current work period is completed, there is still a lot to achieve as we have to recover BAS personnel and survey equipment from James Ross Island before finally returning to the Falkland Islands.







				
	

			Top of page 

			Print

	Harrogate Branch ANNUAL DINNER, - 14 May 2004

	The Harrogate branch will be holding their Annual Dinner in the WO's & Sergeants Mess, Army Foundation College Harrogate at 7.30 p.m. on 14th May 2004. Other GH branches are welcome. Tickets may be obtained from John Leng, Branch Secretary.
	

	THE NATIONAL MALAYA & BORNEO VETERANS ASSOCIATION
Did you serve in the Far East?

    
	
	The National Malaya & Borneo Veterans Association was founded on the 1st June 1994, in order to bring together in true comradeship those who have served and to remember with pride, respect and gratitude those who made the supreme sacrifice.

      
	To date, membership of the Association stands at approximately 5000 world-wide, with over 3000 of those in the United Kingdom mostly enjoying the benefits of 23 Branches nationally. Our aims are simple, to promote and support memorials and public occasions in dedication to the memory of those to whom we owe so much and to further the cause of assistance to those in their time of need. 
	Why not come and join a new Branch starting in your area. 

For more information contact Trevor Kershaw on 01677 424750 or visit the NM&BVA website (www.nmbva.co.uk) 
	




























	
	




	


	



	
Whilst every effort has been taken to ensure the accuracy of this information, personnel must confirm details through the chain of command or with their Administrative Office before taking any action or making any commitment.

		Meet the Crew
		OM (C) Katie Churchill

				
	


								

				

								

			
					
					
					
	
OM (C) K Churchill
My name is Katie Churchill and I’m an Operator Mechanic in the Royal Navy.  I specialise in Communications which enables me to communicate in various ways such as tactical and Morse Code via flashing light.  I am also the Rating In Charge within the Main Communications Office in which I over see the handling of communications within in my watch.  There are also other secondary jobs around the ship that I am responsible for, including the operation of the General Purpose Machine Gun, pretty cool!



I am 19 years old and joined the Royal Navy at the age of 16.  I was born in Johanessburg, South Africa, but I now live in South Witham, a small village just outside of Grantham.  It is here that I enjoy spending time off with my family and friends.

title: Royal Navy
text:
Royal Navy


	
Tue  7 Dec 2004

HMS ENDURANCE USEFUL WEBLINKS






	
	

	HMS Endurance Useful Weblinks





 	If you have enjoyed looking
        at this website and have a further interest in Antarctica and HMS Endurance, you might like to try the following weblinks: 
        

        
	
        The
        British Antarctic Survey (BAS)

 
        The BAS is based in Cambridge. This site provides a rich and
        well-illustrated source of information about Antarctica, The Antarctic
        Treaty and living and working there. HMS Endurance supports BAS Field
        Scientists in and around South Georgia and Antarctica using the ship,
        her helicopters and her boats. Click on www.antarctica.ac.uk

 
	
        The
        United Kingdom Hydrographic Office (UKHO)

 
        The UKHO is based in Taunton. This is the world-renowned centre for the
        production of Admiralty Charts and associated navigation products. HMS
        Endurance’s survey tasking, known as Hydrographic Instructions or
        HI’s, are set by the UKHO and she renders her surveys to the National
        Hydrographer who is based here. Click on: www.hydro.gov.uk

 
	
        Endurance
        ‘Tracking Project’

 
        HMS Endurance contributes regular updates to this project, which is an
        educational resource website that provides further links to science,
        geography and history associated with the places she visits and works.
        It is a popular site and source of information for schools and projects. Click on: www.visitandlearn.co.uk

 
	
        The
        James Caird Society

        
        The James Caird is the 23 foot whaler in which Sir Ernest
        Shackleton and 5 of is men sailed from Elephant Island to South Georgia
        in his epic open boat voyage of 800 miles to secure rescue services in
        his 1914-16 expedition. The boat is preserved now in Dulwich College
        which is his old school in South London. The boat is named after Sir
        James Key Caird, a Dundee jute manufacturer and philanthropist, whose
        generous gift financed the original Endurance expedition. Today, HMS
        Endurance carries a Survey Motor Boat named James Caird, and other boats
        named Stancomb Wills and Dudley Docker which were also boat names in the
        original Endurance. Our other Survey Motor Boat is called Nimrod which
        also has an association with Shackleton and we have yet another boat -
        The 'Captain's Boat' called Eddie Shackleton. HMS Endurance’s links
        with Shackleton are also apparent in the ship's motto is that of the
        Shackleton family - 'By Endurance we conquer'.

        The James Caird Society, established in 1994, is the only
        institution that exists to preserve the memory, and commend the
        outstanding qualities of leadership associated with the name of Sir
        Ernest Shackleton (1874-1922).

        Click on: www.dulwich.org.uk
        

 
	
        South
        Georgia

        
        HMS Endurance assisted the Government of South Georgia and the Sandwich
        Islands with the production of a website that was constructed by a team
        from Dundee University under a project entitled ‘Atlantis’. This is
        an informative and lavishly illustrated site all about South Georgia,
        its whaling history of the past, and the abundant wildlife that lives
        there today. It is an island just 120 miles by 30 mile with a 9000-foot
        mountain range along its spine, yet it is home to 20 million penguins,
        12 million seabirds and 500,000seals. The website also includes a
        special section aimed at children. 

 Click on: www.sgisland.org

 
	
        Falkland
        Islands

 
        HMS Endurance is a frequent visitor to the Falkland Islands on her way
        south, between each work period in South Georgia and Antarctica, and
        before she returns home. She also carries out survey work and support to
        the Falklands Islands Government during these periods. The Falklands
        Islands also has abundant wildlife and rich natural beauty. 

 Click on: www.falklandsconservation.com

							Wellcome Trust Centre for Human Genetics official opening

								
									
								Baruch Blumberg of Fox Chase Cancer Center was one of the guests of honour at the ‘Grand Opening’ of the Henry Wellcome Building of Genomic Medicine, home to the Wellcome Trust Centre for Human Genetics, on 20 June 2000. Dr Blumberg buried a specially prepared ‘time capsule’ to mark the occasion. Other invited speakers included Professor Robert Elston  (Case Western Reserve University), Professor Kenneth Kendler (Virginia Institute for Psychiatric and Behavioral Genetics), Professor Klaus Rajewsky (University of Cologne) and Wayne Hendrickson (Columbia University). Under its Director, Professor Anthony Monaco, the Centre is exploring the genetic basis of common diseases such as heart disease and psychiatric disorders.


		
	Wellcome News Q4 1999: Analysis article describing malaria vaccine research

Wellcome Trust Review 2000: Articles describing Alain Hovnanian and Anthony Monaco's respective research at the Wellcome Trust Centre for Human Genetics. Order this publication online to read ‘A rash pump’ and ‘Problems with words’

October 2004





	


'HISTORIC DAY FOR TURKEY'S FUTURE' - STRAW MEETS WITH TURKISH FM


(07/10/04)






The Foreign Minister, Jack Straw, congratulated the Turkish Foreign Minister on the EU Commission's recommendation that negotiations be opened with Turkey. The ministers met on 7 October 2004 with Mr Straw saying he felt priveledged to be in Ankara on such a historic day. He commented: 'The first thing I did when I saw Minister Gul this morning was to congratulate him and congratulate Prime Minister Erdogan, the government of Turkey and the Turkish people on the extraordinary achievement that has been made in a very short period.'




More...


	



	


EU GIVES POSITIVE SIGNAL TO CANDIDATE COUNTRIES


(06/10/04)






Welcoming the Commission's landmark recommendation that negotiations be opened with Turkey, on Wednesday 6 October 2004, Foreign Secretary, Jack Straw, said: 'I welcome the Commission's latest reports on enlargement, confirming the progress made by all candidate countries towards accession.  Enlargement has been the Union's single most successful external policy, illustrated by the astonishing transformation of Europe, and successful accession on 1 May of ten new Member States.  These reports demonstrate that this progress continues as the security, prosperity and democracy of the EU spreads to more and more countries. The Commission's report has given a clear and positive signal that Turkey has met the Copenhagen political criteria.'

title: Royal Navy
text:
Royal Navy


	
Tue 16 Nov 2004

09 MAY 04






	
	

	09 May 04



HMS Sutherland has had a very busy programme over the last few months.  The main focus has been recovering and enhancing the Ship’s Operational Capability following our return from the Gulf in December.  This has been a multi-stranded effort which has encompassed training, a large engineering effort and, not least, a chance for the Ship’s Company to take leave and spend some time with their families.



Prior to Easter leave HMS Sutherland undertook an intensive Fleet Time Support Period when, supported by SFM and DML, she carried out a substantial engineering work package to ensure the Ship is materially ready to meet the challenges that lie ahead.



Two weeks leave to recharge the batteries was followed by a few days of recovery trials and an intensive training period where the Ship’s Company was put through it’s paces by teams from Flag Officer Sea Training’s organisation.  Sutherland acquitted herself well and proved that she was ready to embark on the important AURORA 04 deployment as part of the UK’s Joint Rapid Reaction Force.



Sutherland deploys on early May 04 to rendezvous with the Amphibious Assault Ship, HMS Albion.  As part of the UK’s Amphibious Task Force she will head across the Atlantic to take part in Exercise RAPID ALLIANCE.  This exercise is a vast amphibious exercise involving forces from the UK, USA, Germany, Canada and Holland.  Whilst on the other side of “The Pond” Sutherland will visit Norfolk (Virginia), Fort Lauderdale, Key West and New Orleans before returning to Devonport in July.

i-uk.com








	


	


						



	
	
	



	



	
			
	





		
	
	



	

















































	
















BASIC INFORMATION



Full Country Name: The Rwandese Republic















































































	









Area: 26,338 sq km

Population: 7,954,013

Capital City: Kigali (305,700)

People: Hutu 84%, Tutsi 15%, Twa (Pygmy) 1%

Language(s): Kinyarwanda (official), French (official), English (official), Kiswhili (Swahili) used in commercial centres.

Religion(s): Roman Catholic 65%, Protestant 9%, Muslim 1%, indigenous beliefs and other 25%.

Currency: 1 Rwandan franc = 100 centimes

Major political parties: Rwandese Patriotic Front (RPF); Rwanda Democratic Movement (MDR); the Social Democratic Party (PSD); Liberal Party (PL); Christian Democratic Party (PDC); Islamic Democratic Party (PDI)

Government: Republic

Head of State: President Paul Kagame (since 22 April 2000)

Prime Minister/Premier: Bernard Makuza (since 8 March 2000)

Foreign Minister: Dr Charles Murigande

GEOGRAPHY


Rwanda, a small land-locked country lying south of the Equator in Central Africa, borders the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), Uganda, Tanzania and Burundi. It has a temperate climate with two rainy seasons (March to May; October to December). Official languages are French, English and Kinyarwanda. Christianity is the majority religion. 


HISTORY


Recent History


Rwandan society traditionally has been portrayed as consisting of three groups, Hutu (84%), Tutsi (15%), and Twa (only 1%). Historically Hutus were numerically stronger, but Tutsi formed the governing class. Rwanda gained independence from Belgian in 1962, and was subsequently ruled by Hutu-dominated governments. From 1972 to 1994, Rwanda was ruled by a one-party system under Hutu President Habyarimana. The Tutsis, many of whom fled Rwanda after widespread massacres in 1959, were excluded from power. Massacres continued throughout the 1960s and Tutsis continued to be excluded. Some gathered in Uganda where they formed the Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF) and its armed wing, the Rwandan Patriotic Army (RPA). 


After 15 years of relative calm, ethnic animosity increased in October 1990, when the RPA invaded the northeast of Rwanda from Uganda, with the objective of restoring democracy. They were halted by the national Forces Armees Rwandaises (FAR). Stalemate ensued. Regional states encouraged President Habyarimana to agree to a new power-sharing settlement, which he signed in Arusha (Tanzania) in April 1994. As he flew back to Kigali on 6 April, his plane was shot down. This was the signal for the genocide to start. Roadblocks were quickly erected and a full-scale programme of genocide against Tutsis and moderate Hutus began. The extremists were supported by Hutu peasants, incited to kill by ethnic propaganda. 


The RPA launched a major offensive to drive out the FAR and end the genocide. The RPA’s first offensive was halted by a coalition of FAR and Zairean troops. The RPA regrouped. By 4 July when they reached Kigali around 800,000 people had been murdered, and over 1 million refugees and perpetrators had fled. This was the largest organised genocide since the Second World War.


Following the capture of Kigali on 4 July 1994, the RPF formed a Government of National Unity based on the power-sharing agreement reached in Arusha, but excluding those parties that had planned the genocide. Pasteur Bizimungu, a Hutu, was appointed President, with Paul Kagame (the Commander of the RPA), a Tutsi, as his deputy. Although the RPF had a minority of Cabinet seats and Assembly places, they dominated the government's policies. Following the resignation of President Bizimungu in March 2000, Paul Kagame became President of Rwanda on 6 April.


Attacks on Rwanda, particularly the northwest, by FAR and those responsible for the perpetration of the genocide, the Interahamwe continued from eastern Zaire. The Government of Rwanda called on the international community to disarm the ex-FAR and Interahamwe, but no action was taken. 

In late 1996, the RPA backed a rebellion in eastern Zaire, which destroyed the refugee camps and resulted in the overthrow of the former Zairean regime of Mobutu Sese Seko in May 1997. After some weeks over a million refugees returned to Rwanda. Many ex-FAR and Interahamwe escaped and remained in Zaire.


By August 1998, an upsurge in attacks on north-western Rwanda by FAR/Interahamwe forces and continuing insecurity on Rwanda’s western border led Rwanda, initially in coalition with Uganda, again to back a rebellion in eastern DRC. The fighting involved DRC forces and their Zimbabwean, Chadian, Angolan and Namibian allies on one side and rebels supported by Uganda and Rwanda on the other. By the time a cease-fire agreement was signed in Lusaka (Zambia) in autumn 1999, the rebels controlled large areas in the north and east.  Little progress was made on implementing the Lusaka Agreement, and in mid-2002 South African President Mbeki, in his capacity as African Union chair, felt compelled to broker a new agreement between the DRC and Rwanda. 

The Pretoria Accord was signed on 30 July 2002, and provided for Rwandan withdrawal of its troops from the DRC, and the DRC Government to stop all support for the ex-FAR/Interahamwe and to facilitate their disarmament, demobilisation and repatriation. Rwandan forces completed their withdrawal ahead of schedule on 5 October 2002, although there have been continued allegations that certain Rwandan elements had remained. Equally, despite some ad hoc repatriation of foreign armed groups, the ex-FAR/Interahamwe continued to organise militarily in DRC with the support of elements of the Kinshasa government.

The current Rwandan Government avoids use of ethnic labels, and has argued that divisions within Rwandan society, where the population shares a common language, religion and lifestyle, is not ‘ethnic’ but the result of a colonial divide-and-rule policy perpetuated by previous post independence single-party governments. Since 1996, categorisation by ethnic group no longer appears on Rwandan citizens’ compulsory identity cards.   


POLITICS

Rwanda held a referendum on 26 May 2003 on a new Constitution. This was subsequently adopted by Parliament. Presidential and parliamentary elections followed in August and September 2003. Paul Kagame was re-elected President with 95% of the vote. Although international observers reported some irregularities in the electoral process, voting was generally well-run and orderly. 


International Tribunal/Judicial System


The United Nations Security Council established the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (ICTR) in 1994. Its role is to investigate the Rwandan genocide and indict and prosecute those who bear the greatest responsibility for acts of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity. It is based in Arusha, Tanzania. ICTR have been successful in tracking, arresting and extraditing indicted suspects, although the pace of the trials has been slow. The detention centre at Arusha is highly secure, modern and well designed. 


ICTR handed down its first verdict on 2 September 1998, when Jean-Paul Akayesu, former mayor of Taba Commune, was found guilty of Genocide, Direct and Public Incitement to Commit Genocide and Crimes against Humanity and sentenced to life imprisonment. The ICTR has now convicted 23 people. In October 2003 the ICTR presented its completion strategy to the UN. This foresees completing of all investigations by the end of 2004, and the eventual winding up of ICTR in 2010. 


However ICTR only deals with the main perpetrators of the genocide. Around 100,000 detainees are in prisons in Rwanda. The Rwandan Government will not countenance mass amnesty for those suspected of involvement in the genocide, but the numbers in detention are beyond its capability to deal with through the conventional judicial process. The Government therefore adapted a traditional form of justice – gacaca – to deal with certain categories of crime related to the genocide. International observers, including human rights organisations, have criticised the lack of legal representation for the defendants and over-crowded prison conditions.  40,000 prisoners have been released in advance of the gacaca process as they had confessed to their crimes. Following a successful pilot, gacaca is being rolled out countrywide.


The UK has provided voluntary assistance to ICTR, including financial and human resources in addition to our UN assessed contribution. The international community is also providing assistance to alleviate prison conditions, and to rebuild the judiciary in Rwanda. 


ECONOMY


Basic Economic Facts 


GDP: US$ 1.7 bn (2002)

GDP Growth: 3.5% (2003 est)

Inflation: 5.5% (2002 est)

Major Exports: Coffee, tea, coltan, cassiterite

Major Trading Partners: Exports – Germany (17.7%), Pakistan (7.4%). Imports – Kenya, Belgium, US, Japan

Exchange Rate: Rwanda Franc 1018 = £1 (August 2004)





























	









	








UK Trade & Investment Country Profile: Rwanda













INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS


Rwanda's Relations with Neighbours


Relations between Rwanda and Uganda are improving. The UK has facilitated trilateral meetings between Presidents Kagame and Museveni and the Secretary of State for International Development, most recently held on 29 January 2004. 



Rwanda's involvement in the DRC conflict damaged its relations with the Kinshasa government. Despite numerous meetings and agreement to improve bilateral relations, these remain strained, with accusations from both sides that the measures agreed to at Pretoria in 2002 have not been adhered to. Relations hit a low point during May and June 2004 when the DRC accused Rwanda of backing rebels who briefly took control of the Congolese town of Bukavu. UN forces on the ground could neither confirm nor deny this. Rwanda has taken an active role in its participation at the African Union. Rwanda deployed 150 troops to protect the African Union’s monitoring mission in Darfur, Sudan on 15 August.


RWANDA'S RELATIONS WITH THE UK 

Diplomatic Representation

UK representation in Rwanda

Rwandan representation in the UK

The first Rwandan Embassy in Britain was established in 1995. A British Embassy was also established in Rwanda at the same time. 


UK Development Assistance


The UK is the largest bilateral donor in Rwanda. In 1999 we made a ten-year commitment to a development programme. In financial year 2003/2004 the UK provided £37 million and in financial year 2004/2005 will provide £43m. A Memorandum of Understanding between Rwanda and the UK was signed in January 2004 which reaffirmed our commitment to Rwanda’s redevelopment. 

Trade and Investment with the UK


Rwanda is a country offering few trade opportunities for UK companies. There are some mineral resources, notably methane gas, but exploitation is costly. Rwanda is trying to help increase commercial opportunities and is committed to a privatisation programme of the following state-owned service enterprises: telecommunications, water and electricity, gas, transport and mining. There could be limited opportunities for UK companies here. UK exports to Rwanda in 2003 were £3.2 million, with UK imports from Rwanda in the same year totalling £ 0.25 million.



Recent Visits 


Outward: Jack Straw, Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs (January 2002), Hilary Benn, Secretary of State for International Development (April 2004) and Chris Mullin, Minister for Africa (June 2004).


Inward: President Paul Kagame (March 2003, May 2003, January 2004), Dr Charles Murigande, Foreign Minister (May 2003), Prime Minister Makuza (November 2003). 


HUMAN RIGHTS


While abuses continue to be reported, progress is being made in raising awareness of human rights. Many NGOs continue to focus on education and reconciliation in the wake of the genocide. 


The UN Human Rights Field Office in Rwanda operated until July 1998, when the Rwandan authorities suspended its activities. The Government has since established a National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) and a National Unity and Reconciliation Commission (NURC). 


SANCTIONS


UN Security Council resolutions 918 (1994), 997 (1995) and 1011 (1995) impose restrictions on the sale or supply of arms and related material to Rwanda and also to persons in States neighbouring Rwanda (DRC, Uganda, Tanzania and Burundi) when the goods in question are intended for use in Rwanda. To implement these measures the United Nations Arms Embargoes Orders 1993-1998, as amended by the United Nations (Sanctions) (Amendment) Order 2000, set out the licensing requirements in the UK in relation to such sale or supply. Corresponding Orders exist for the Overseas Territories and Crown Dependencies. 



TRAVEL

Travel Advice: Rwanda

Last updated - 18 August 2004
Foreign & Commonwealth Office Country Profiles

title: Royal Navy
text:
Royal Navy


	
Tue 30 Nov 2004

LS(HQ) FRAN STOFFELL






	
	

	
LS(HQ) Fran Stoffell
Fran and her husband, David (who is a serving officer in the Royal Navy) live with their son, Christopher (17) in Derriford, Plymouth.  They also have a daughter, Caroline (19), who is studying in London.



Fran joined the RNR 13 years ago and is trained to work in Operational Headquarters.  She is frequently to be found at Flag Officer Sea Training in Plymouth, where her skills as a member of HMS Vivid’s shooting team come in handy when ship’s companies are being trained to deal with terrorist attacks!  Fran has also worked at the NATO Headquarters in Northwood and in Gibraltar.  During the day Fran can be found in St Budeaux, where she is a primary school teacher.



At the Presentation of the Sovereign’s Colour to the Royal Naval Reserve, which took place at Horse Guards Parade in London on 17th May 2003, Fran had the honour of forming part of the escort to the Sovereign’s Colour.  Before the ceremony, Fran said “I spent much of my childhood in London; my father was in the Army and I watched numerous ceremonial parades on Horse Guards, but I never expected to be in one myself – let alone playing a major part such as this.”

					Surface Fleet

		HMS Endurance
		Meet the Crew 1
		CPO AEA Iain Palmer

				
	


								

				

								

			
					
					
					
	Chief Petty Officer Air Engineering Artificer Iain Palmer



My name is Iain Palmer, I’m 38 and married to Trudi and have a 9 year old daughter Caitlin, we live in Portland, Dorset. I miss my family very much when I’m on deployment in HMS Endurance.



I work as a Watch Chief on 212 Flight operating two Lynx helicopters. They both have red noses and doors to make them easy to see against the ice.



This season will be my sixth season in Antarctica; it is an amazing place full of the most wonderful scenery and wildlife. I love watching all the different kinds of penguins which live in Antarctica and South Georgia. Seeing whales in the wild is pretty special too.



I spend a lot of time flying to different parts of Antarctica where I sometimes work ashore organizing loads and passengers for helicopter flights back to the ship or to some of the British Antarctic Survey Bases.



I’m looking forward to seeing my family in Cape Town, South Africa when the ship visits there on the way home next year. I also can’t wait to play some golf when I get some time off.

title: Palliative and supportive care links
text:
Palliative and supportive care links
    
      Skip navigation
    



	 
	 
	


    

 
	 
  		

    


    
    



    
      


      Palliative and supportive care links


      ?


      On this page are gathered some useful links to places on the Internet that you
      may find useful. This list is anything but exhaustive.


      
      
      Marie Curie
      
      


      This is the main site for Marie Curie Cancer Care. It tells you all
      about what it does. Not much we could find in the way of hard evidence, but the
      stories from professionals and others are interesting, and at least let you know
      that you are not alone.


      
      
      Kings Palliative Care Dept
      
      


      This takes you into the website of the joint department of King's
      College School of Medicine and St Christopher's Hospice. It has information on the
      Master's degree in palliative care. It has access to the Halley Stewart Library,
      the specialist library at St Christopher's, and you can also fins all the
      department's publications from the mid 1990s. Lots of interesting stuff there, and
      the site looks as if it is still growing. Well worth a visit.


      
      
      Hospice Foundation of America
      
      


      As it says, this is a US site with lots of information, including
      that off how to locate a hospice in the USA.


      
      
      Robert Wood Johnson Foundation
      
      


      Here you can find the end of life physician education resource
      centre (EPERC). It is, as advertised, a resource, with a some good educational
      materials, information on publications, including videos, it has a discussion
      forum, and you can submit materials to it.


      
      
      Institute of Cancer Research
      
      


      Much on this site, but we really found the list of cancer-related
      Internet sites first-class. It is a well designed site, fast and easy to
      navigate.


      
      
      UK Palliative Care links
      
      


      This page of useful links for palliative care in the UK is set up
      and run by John Chambers, the Specialist Registrar at St Katherine's House Hospice,
      in Adderbury, Oxford, close to where 
      Bandolier

       has enjoyed many a happy and not so happy hour on the golf course. It seems to
      cover so many useful links (National Council, Macmillan, Fundraisers and so on that
      it seems superfluous to repeat them.
