title: Draft Let for ACC_O_ re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strateg…
text:
Draft Let for ACC_O_ re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strateg…Our Ref: January 2003
Ms Hazel Blears
SU/DoH Consultation
Room 4.6
Admiralty Arch
The Mall
London      SW1A 2WH
Dear Ms Blears
NATIONAL ALCOHOL HARM REDUCTION STRATEGY
Following consultation with key members of the Force, I am now in a position to respond to
your consultation document dated 15 October 2002.
For ease of reading, I have completed this Force’s replies to correspond with the numbered
questions outlined in your document.
THE PRINCIPLES THAT SHOULD UNDERPIN THE STRATEGY
1 Why should the Government get involved in managing the harmful effects of alcohol
misuse?
In a perfect world it would be nice to think that those responsible for the manufacture, sale
and supply of alcohol could be relied upon to be self-regulating without the need for any
legislation or Government intervention.  The reality is, however, that there will always be
unscrupulous operators who will put profit before the welfare of the public.
The Government should take the lead and give clear guidelines.
2 How far is alcohol misuse a matter of individual responsibility and when does
Government have a responsibility to intervene, whether through services, legislation
or persuasion?
Alcohol in moderation can be medically beneficial and allow people to enjoy leisure
pursuits, but alcohol in excess can lead to health problems, poor performance at work and
absenteeism and can be a catalyst for committing criminal offences.  Whilst to some extent
C:\TEMP\Draft Let for ACC(O) re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy      13.01.03.docindividuals must take responsibility for their own actions, as with all things in life,
guidelines must be given to curb excessive use of alcohol.
3 How can we strike a balance between individual and community rights and choices?
Alcohol is a drug sold under licence.  The sale and distribution must be carefully monitored
to protect the rights of all persons, not just the minority.  Safe drinking areas on premises
should be encouraged so that it can be pleasant for those drinking without adversely
impacting on the local community.
4 What are the respective roles and responsibilities of consumers, voluntary groups,
commercial interest and others?
Everyone involved in the drinks industry, either as customers or suppliers, have a
responsibility to ensure that alcohol can be ‘used’ and not ‘abused’.  It is only the minority of
people who cause problems for everyone and these individuals must be targeted by
encouraging (if necessary by legislation) well run premises where alcohol abuse will not be
tolerated.
5 What principles should underpin a national alcohol harm reduction strategy?
(i) Individual rights should be protected, but this should not affect other peoples quality of
life.
(ii) There must be partnerships and a multi-agency approach to tackling licensing issues.
(iii) Licensees and operators must be given clear guidelines
(iv) Drink brands/labels specifically targeting the young and vulnerable (underage) should
be stopped.
THE CULTURE AND BEHAVIOURAL ISSUES AROUND ALCOHOL USE
AND MISUSE
6 How do you define alcohol misuse?  What factors do you take into account?
Alcohol is misused when it has a detrimental effect on an individual or the impact of that
misuse affects the quality of life for other people.  Factors to be taken into account include
affect on health, impact on other people, impact on family life, anti-social and unreasonable
behaviour and the link between alcohol and violent criminal offences.
7 What drinking patterns should an alcohol harm reduction strategy seek to affect?  How
susceptible are such patterns to change?  Where should Government concentrate its
efforts in prevention?
Binge drinking and drinking with the aim of getting drunk.  Despite numerous initiatives,
these patterns continue to be a cause for concern and the Government should concentrate its
efforts in educating young people with particular emphasis in health and the consequences of
alcohol misuse.
C:\TEMP\Draft Let for ACC(O) re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy      13.01.03.doc8 Is there a relationship between trends in drinking and wider social change – eg the
spread of higher education, changes in workplace culture, later marriage and/or family
formation?  Where does this suggest we need to focus attention in influencing
behaviour?
Social standards have changed and this, together with more prosperity in the Country, can
encourage drinking trends.  Young people, at present, have more spare money than anytime in
history and with the spending culture in the Country, operators are vying for their trade.  This
includes the alcohol industry who, through promotions and venues, are targeting young
people.  We need to focus our attention to educating young people so that they are more
aware of the impact of alcohol and are encouraged to take a mature approach in considering
their drinking habits.
Schemes such as ‘alcohol referral schemes’ should be made more widely available to target
hardened drinkers who commit criminal offences.  Tackle the underlying problem is the way
forward but these schemes need financing.
9  One group we need to focus on specifically is young people where the evidence suggests a
rise in  consumption, particularly young women.  Are there other groups we should be
focusing on?  For example, are there specific issues around minority ethnic attitudes to,
and use of alcohol which we should bring into our analysis?
There are sections of society who are affected by alcohol misuse and in general terms these
groups are as follows:-
(i) Under 18’s obtaining alcohol illegally or drinking at home.
(ii) 18-25 year old, male and females, involved in weekend late night binge drinking usually
in town centres which cause the majority of public disorder incidents.
(iii) Persons with social problems which could include health, family problems, poverty and
money problems.
(iv) Hardened drinkers and alcoholics who possibly could have a dependency problem.
(v) Stress related (usually hidden and secretive) which can affect parts of the community
with whom the police do not normally have any contact – eg:- persons in business
professions.
10 It is easy to focus on the negative aspects of alcohol use and misuse, but what are the
positive cultural and behavioural (as opposed to economic) aspects?  What parts of our
culture would change for the worse if we did not have alcohol?
In some areas, particularly rural communities, the ‘pub’ is the heart and social centre of the
village and, to some extend, it has the same function in the rural areas of towns.  Apart from
meeting for a drink, many venues have a good selection of food and they also support sports
teams such as football, cricket, skittles and darts but also other events such as quiz nights and
music nights.  Without such a venue for interaction, people would become insular and
boredom is often the catalyst for committing criminal offences and anti-social behaviour.
If alcohol were not available, people may turn to drugs for some form of stimulant.
C:\TEMP\Draft Let for ACC(O) re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy      13.01.03.doc11 Is there such a thing as a recognisably English drinking culture and, if so, what does it
look like?  What are the factors which influence it – for example, are there sharp
regional differences?  Does it look different for different age groups ?
The old fashioned village pub atmosphere does still exist in many areas which enhances
community spirit but, because it is quiet and causes no problems, very little publicity is given
to this way of life.
In more recent years ‘binge drinking’ has hit the headlines and it is mainly associated with
young people and is considered by many people to be an English disease involving ‘yob’
culture.  Reasons for this are varied but, to generalise, young people today have more
freedom than ever before, there are many more disfunctional families where there is little or
no discipline or proper role model and young people have more money to spend.  At night,
town and city centres are the haunt of young people with accessibility to nightclubs and late
night fun pubs and takeaways.  The venues are designed to encourage the young and very
few older people feel comfortable in these areas or venues.  Also, it is mainly these venues
who have drinks promotions such as (i) buy one get one free (ii) special deals such as pints of
beer for £1.00 or (iii) nightclubs who change a £15.00 admission and allow customers to
drink free all night.  These type of promotions encourage excess drinking.
12 What factors influence behaviour – fashion and marketing, family background,
education and information, financial, legal and regulatory, scientific, environmental?
Which are the most influential in your view? How easy is it to exert influence through
those factors?
All these factors impact on the drinking culture but the most influential is ‘Marketing’ and
‘Peer pressure’.  There are voluntary schemes such as the Portman Group scheme which bans
unsuitable labelled products from its premises but, marketing being what it is, there will need
to be legislation to enforce this type of scheme throughout the licensing trade.  Peer pressure
can only be influenced by education.
13 How do attitudes to risk affect use of alcohol?
In general, people do not take the risk factor into account when drinking.  This is more so in
the young who, at that age, consider themselves invincible.  It is only when a medical
problem occurs as a result of heavy drinking, or someone commits an alcohol related
offence, which impacts on their lives such as being banned for drink driving, that people
consider the consequences.
C:\TEMP\Draft Let for ACC(O) re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy      13.01.03.docHEALTH:  PREVENTION, TREATMENT AND THE IMPACT ON THE
NHS
14 How do you define drinking?  What factors do you take into account in deciding
whether heavy drinking has become problematic drinking?
I would define ‘harmful drinking’ as excessive consumption of alcohol that causes long-term
health problems and where the person concerned is unable to function as a normal member of
society.  The factors to be taken into account are:
(i) Where the individual cannot/will not recognise that he/she has a problem
(ii) Where a problem has been identified but he/she is unable to deal with it.
(iii) Where a problem has a detrimental effect on a persons work life.
(iv) Where the drinking causes disruption and problems for family and friends, often
leading to criminality.
Questions 15 – 22 inclusive, directly refers to NHS issues and we are not qualified to
comment on these issues.
CRIME, DISORDER AND ANTI-SOCIAL BEHAVIOUR:  THE EFFECTS
ON OUR SURROUNDINGS AND COMMUNITY
23 What evidence is there about the links between alcohol and crime and the links between
alcohol and anti-social behaviour?  Are there key studies or pieces of evidence you
think we should be aware of?  Where are the gaps in the evidence?
Undoubtedly, alcohol can be linked to crime and anti-social behaviour in the community.  It
is widely accepted that offences such as criminal damage, public disorder and assaults can be
linked to excessive consumption of alcohol and the resultant loss of inhibitions.  These tend
to be street offences in our cities and towns but also includes more serious offences caused
by alcohol fuelled domestic violence.
There have been studies and evidence over the years, such as the Government’s own
publications “Taking Stock” and there have been surveys by the Portman Group.
24 In your experience, is alcohol a factor in habitual re-offending?  Does it lead to
particular types of crime ?  How far does it lead to one-off offences?
Alcohol can often lead to violent crime, which is invariably spontaneous. That being said, it
can become habit forming especially in incidents of domestic violence or drunken persons
acting aggressively provoking people.  This conduct can continue until checked in some way
such as a ban on drink driving or a court appearance.
25 To what extent can alcohol convincingly be demonstrated to be a factor in criminal and
disorderly behaviour?  How much is perception and how much is reality?  What fuels
the perceptions and are they accurate?
C:\TEMP\Draft Let for ACC(O) re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy      13.01.03.docA large proportion of crime and disorder can be attributed to people under the influence of
alcohol.  These factors are borne out by observations from police patrols, dealing with
witnesses and offenders subject of criminal matters and interviewing offenders.  Numerous
custody sheets for specific offences, at the relevant times, are endorsed “under the influence
of alcohol”.  Also many police logs are updated that alcohol was a contributory factor.
26 Alcohol is far from being the only factor in crime and disorder.  Other factors are
involved – for example, town centre disorder can be influenced by lack of availability of
transport or design of environment.  What other factors might be involved?  How easy
are these factors to influence?  Who is responsible for them?
Other factors that have an impact on crime and town/city centre disorder are the location and
numbers of late night licensed venues.  Many of these close at the same time causing large
groups to congregate in the town/city centres.  This causes competition for taxis and take-
away food outlets, which combined with the consumption of alcohol, leads to confrontation
and disorder.
It would assist if proprietors of late night food outlets take more responsibility for the
behaviour of their customers. The late night pubs/clubs have to ensure that they have
sufficient trained staff to deal with any disorder whereas there is no regulation or control on
late night food outlets.
27 How does the impact of alcohol on urban environments differ from its impact on rural
environments?  Whar are the differences between urban and rural drinking patterns
and how do they affect those communities and surroundings?
In urban areas, there is a greater density of licensed premises and this has the obvious effect
of generating more customers, greater congestion of people and traffic and later opening  for
licensed premises and food outlets.  This usually generates more “hussle and bustle” and
leads to more confrontational situations.
Whilst in rural areas, the same facilities are not available in that there are normally no late
night venues or late food outlets.  Transportation is normally not an issue in that people either
drive, walk or order taxis at the end of the evening.  As a result, there are not the
confrontation flash points that there are in the urban environment.
When there are particular rural drink related incidents, the concern amongst local residents is
greater than a similar incident merits in urban areas.  The reason for this is that the
expectations of people living in the areas are different.  Rural residents are not as tolerant to
disturbance/disorder as the people who chose to live in towns and cities.
28 To what extent can impact on the environment (including crime, disorder, noise and
waste) be designed out, for example by use of plastic glasses?  Are there examples of
good practice it would be helpful for us to be aware of?
In this police area there are examples of good practice where a range of organisations and
partnerships deal with different aspects of alcohol successfully.  These are as follows:
C:\TEMP\Draft Let for ACC(O) re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy      13.01.03.doc(i) The use of arrest referral schemes based at the Custody Centres.  Financing these
schemes is always an issue but the one at Exeter is run by multi-agency funding.
Another in Cornwall (Operation Amethyst) is funded by a Home Office grant.
Although these are excellent schemes, there are still hurdles to be overcome in
connection with the sharing of information between the agencies involved.
(ii) We have a number of Licensees Associations who work closely with the Police and
this has proved to be a useful forum for the exchange of ideas and information.  By
working together, we have been able to tackle crime and disorder, e.g. banned
persons lists, early warning pager messages between the police and licensed premises
and processing intelligence.
(iii) The use of toughened glasses in late night licensed premises occurs throughout the
Force with the support of the Local Authorities imposing these conditions on the
Public Entertainment Licences.
(iv) The use of plastic bottles has not been so successful.  There is strong opposition to
this condition for late night venues by the licensed trade and BEDA.  There are
sixteen local authority areas in this Force and only two have adopted this as a
condition of the Public Entertainment Licence.  Any injury caused by glass,
particularly on the face, can leave terrible scars and affect the aggrieved persons
health, family and job prospects.  (It would put many employees off if someone came
for a job interview with a scarred face).
(v) Make full use of the new powers under the Police and Criminal Justice Act 2001 to
impose no drinking zones in designated public areas after consultation with relevant
agencies and local people.  One problem with this new power is that police cannot
seize alcohol in a sealed container.  This has caused operational problems when
dealing with drunken youths hanging around street corners drinking alcohol from
cans.  The police can seize the open cans but it does cause embarrassment for the
police that unopened cans are left with the youths.  Rumours of this loophole are
doing the rounds of the schools and this could lead to police baiting by some unco-
operative youths.
(vi) The use of CCTV has had a major impact on rural areas.  Local people are aware that
they could be monitored and in some cases it might cause potential offenders to think
before they commit an offence.  When offences or incidents do occur, CCTV
evidence is often relied upon to prove what happened.  The downside of CCTV is that
potential problems can be displaced to affect other areas.
(vii) Late night takeaways often generate a lot of debris in the vicinity of their shop, such
as discarded cartons, paper, food and cans.  Whilst they have a right to run a business,
it is felt that they should be made responsible for cleaning up the mess generated.
This should be done when the takeaway is closing and cover up to a 50 feet radius
from the frontage of the premises. (Such a culture is evident in Germany).  Tidy, well
kept areas give respectability and often influence people to better behaviour and
provides an environment which reduces the fear of crime whereas untidy areas means
lower standards and anything goes.
(viii) Adequate street lighting is necessary in the vicinity of late night licensed premises
and takeaways.  People are less inclined to commit offences where they can easily be
seen.
29 There are some examples of good practice where a range of organisations responsible
for dealing with different aspects of alcohol, have successfully ‘combined efforts’ and
shared information to tackle alcohol-related crime and disorder together.  Should this
C:\TEMP\Draft Let for ACC(O) re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy      13.01.03.docapproach be encouraged more widely?  What inhibits organisations or communities
from taking such an approach?
The partnership approach is essential and it must be encouraged.
There are several reasons inhibiting such an approach:
(i) Local communities.  Local residents often lack leadership or a united voice.  Effort
has to be made (usually by a local individual) to try and encourage people to support
local issues.
(ii) Costs involved.  Initiatives such as using plastic bottles in late night venues are
opposed by the drinks industry because they state it costs 10% more to produce
plastic bottles.
(iii) People’s time and involvement.  These partnership initiatives are usually in addition
to work that people are already doing.  Most people are very busy and to take an extra
responsibilities is often not a welcome task.
30 Is it right that anti-crime and anti-social behaviour initiatives need to be targeted on
young people?
The simple answer to that is ‘yes’.  They are the ones to influence and educate to break the
mode of “binge drinking”.
31  Should we be encouraging different drinking patterns – in terms of time spent drinking
location of drinking etc – in order to tackle alcohol-related crime and disorder?
It is hoped that the new licensing act will encourage different drinking patterns by allowing
communities a say in deciding operating hours for licensed premises.  With a more relaxed
attitude to opening hours people should be able to drink at a slower rate over a longer period
of time and with the same amount of money to spend they should not get so intoxicated.
It is necessary to stop this ‘drink until you drop culture” which appears to be a favourite
weekend activity for the young.  Whilst some older people will cause problems, generally
speaking these people have less money to spend as they have families to look after and
mortgages.
32 How can the law on, and policing approaches to public drunkenness and street
drinking help to tackle these problems?  Are existing controls and powers (such as
those for local authorities to introduce no drinking zones) effective? Are they
sufficient?
As indicated in question (28) the police continue to try different initiatives to tackle these
problems.  Alcohol is normally supplied from licensed premises and more onus should be
put on the licensee to shoulder some of the responsibility of customers committing
offences in the vicinity of licensed premises.  In practice when an incident occurs, the
licensee is questioned and the normal excuse is “they must have got drunk elsewhere”.  If
disorder occurs in the area which is drink related then there should be powers to have
licensed premises (in a designated radius) restricted on opening times.  This type of
restriction affects licensee’s profits and it would encourage them to keep an orderly house
C:\TEMP\Draft Let for ACC(O) re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy      13.01.03.docand not sell alcohol to drunks.  Peer pressure by other licensees in the vicinity would
encourage all licensed premises to comply.
The police end up tackling the problem after it has occurred, the licensee has the power to
stop the problem occurring.
Also cheap drink promotions should not be allowed in the late night licensed premises as it
encourages drunkenness.
33 One person’s good evening out can be another persons’ sleepless night.  Are there
principles to guide the balance of individual rights and responsibilities?
There is legislation to deal with disorder or violence on the streets but the police have a
limited number of officers and it is impossible to stop a certain amount of noise occurring.
A partnership approach with private and public sector organisations is essential.
34 Drink – drive polices are generally acknowledged to be successful.  What can we
learn from this?
The culture has changed over the last 25 years to community intolerance to drink drive.
The reasons for this change should be analysed to identify key ingredients which may
assist in other alcohol related criminality. Apart from social unacceptability, one of the
main factors with drink drive offences is that the guilty person is banned from driving for
normally at least one year.  Not only does the loss of the driving licence lead to
inconveniences and increased insurance premiums but also in many cases it could cause
that person to loose their job.  Many jobs are driving related or necessitate the use of a
vehicle to get to and from work and such a ban would mean that person would probably be
sacked.  This penalty has forced motorists to confront the problem which has let to a
change in attitudes.
Unless the penalty for other drink related offences is severe enough to cause
inconvenience to the offender then it is doubtful that it make a person reflect on their own
drinking habits.
35 Domestic violence is often associated with alcohol misuse – either by the perpetrator,
or on occasion, by the victim.  What in your experience, is the nature of this link and
what would you see as good practice in tackling the interrelationship between
domestic violence and alcohol misuse?
Alcohol abuse cause strained relationships in families which can be lead to domestic
violence.  This Force has domestic violence officers who assist victims and sometimes
offenders to face and sort out their problems.  Advice is available to all persons involved.
Alcohol abuse may be considered as a weighting when risk assessing recidivism and
thereby influence preventative measures in support of the victim.
THE IMPLICATIONS FOR VULNERABLE GROUPS
36 Which children and young people do you see as being most vulnerable to the
consequences of alcohol misuse?
C:\TEMP\Draft Let for ACC(O) re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy      13.01.03.docPotentially any child but particularly those in the 12-18 year age group.
37 What other groups would you identify as particularly at risk and vulnerable to
harmful effects of alcohol?
This could include:
(i)    The homeless
 (ii) Children subject to domestic upheaval and violence
 (iii) Children who are under achieving and more prone to peer pressure
 (iv)     Children who are poorly supervised at home or at school.
38 Those who are vulnerable to the consequences of alcohol misuse often have complex
problems (for example they may be homeless and may have additional mental health
or drug problems) and such factors may be inter-related.  What key factors need to
be understood in addition to alcohol use that contribute to maintaining the problems
facing such groups?  Which of these factors should interventions be aimed at?
Key factors linked to vulnerable groups in our society include the following socio-
economic factors: -
(i) Poor parenting
(ii) Poor housing
(iii) Domestic violence
(iv) Economic factors (unemployment/low income)
(v) Family illness/stress
(vi) Poor community support and facilities
(vii) Poor environment
(viii) Law achievement and expectations
Interventions can be focused on any one of these points but key in the approach is the fact
that it should be early intervention i.e in young persons, whilst they are still of primary
school age.
39 How can the services provided by the state and others to vulnerable groups with
complex problems be joined up most effectively?  Are there examples of joined up
delivery it would be helpful for us to be aware of?  What gets in the way of joining
up services?
Joint partnerships do exist such as:
(i) Drug Action Teams, and
(ii)       Youth Offending Teams
Quite often excessive bureaucracy can affect the efficiency and input of such partnerships.
40 How realistically can these vulnerable groups be dealt with by mainstream services
and how far do they need services which are tailored to individual groups and
indeed to individuals on a case-by-case basis?  What is your experience?
C:\TEMP\Draft Let for ACC(O) re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy      13.01.03.docGenetic approach can deal with vulnerable groups to a certain level, but specialist services
are required e.g DAT’s, Alcoholics Anonymous etc.  Each case needs to be dealt with on its
merits.
EDUCATION AND COMMUNICATION
41 What should the objectives in this area?  Is the aim to raise levels of awareness?  Is
it to inform specifically?  Is it to change behaviour?  Are there any particular
successful or unsuccessful examples we should be aware of?
To educate and raise awareness is of primary importance. To change the social culture
against such anti-social behaviour as exemplified with drink/driving.
42 Given clear objectives, what is the evidence on the effectiveness of these approaches?
What do they actually achieve?  How can their effectiveness be measured?
Reduction in anti-social behaviour. Greater feeling of community safety.
  43 How well is the sensible drinking message reaching its audience?  Is it sufficiently
clear?  What is the evidence on its penetration and its effect on behaviour?
It appears to be having little effect.
44 How well is scientific research feeding into alcohol education? Is the message based
on sound unbiased and uncontroversial research and are new findings effectively
incorporated?
Scientific research details “turn off” the targeted audience unless there is a message which
shows there is something in it for the individuals targeted.
45 Should particular groups be targeted for information and communication?  Is there
a need to provide more intensive alcohol education to groups other than young
people (e.g elderly drinkers)?
Educating young people with regard to alcohol use and misuse is important.  In this Force,
Police Youth Affairs Officers work together with School Nurses, School Counsellors, and
Teaching Teams delivering an education programme on the subject misuse.  The basis
being that a drug is any substance that can affect the way our minds or bodies function.
This obviously includes alcohol.
46 What is the role of schools, colleges, universities and other educational institutions in
providing alcohol education as well as support for alcohol-related problems?  How
can we best establish and preserve a healthy learning environment?
Places of education have a major role is providing alcohol education and to maintain this;
a healthy link between the police and such establishments should be encouraged.
C:\TEMP\Draft Let for ACC(O) re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy      13.01.03.doc47 What role is there for families/parents as role models or in educating their children
on sensible levels of alcohol drinking and the risks of alcohol misuse?  How can they
best be informed and engaged in this effort?
Parents and families are role models for children and the way that they behave will have
more impact than what they say.  How to get the message across to parents is not easy but
it could be a multi agency approach via the school links such as an additional presentation
at school open day or something similar.
48 What does experience show on the most effective means of getting messages across?
Are there circumstances in which the Government is particularly well placed to do
so, or conversely might be particularly unsuccessful?
A police led presentation in places of education will probably make the most impact.  The
sight of an uniformed police officer can bring home the seriousness of the subject.
49 What can we learn from educational initiatives in the field of illegal drugs?
Some drug initiatives use former addicts to inform people of how drugs affected their
health, welfare, family life, job prospects etc.  Perhaps a reformed alcoholic could be used
in such a presentation, as it would give people the human aspect rather than just facts and
figures.
50 Do you have views on the existing regulation of advertising on alcohol?
There is not enough regulation, particularly in reflection to cheap drink promotions, which
are advertised in local papers and on billboards.  These advertisements often glamorise the
alcohol drinks so as to be attractive to young people.
THE SHAPE OF THE MARKET AND MARKET-BASED SOLUTIONS
51  Do you have any thoughts on the likely evolution of the alcohol industry over the
next decade?
The consumption of alcohol is likely to increase.  With the new licensing act, there should
be a more liberal, continental style of licensing with increased opening hours.  Unless
there is major conflict or a disaster, prosperity should increase which will give people
more money to spend on leisure activities including alcohol consumption.
52 What is the relationship between the creation of trends and fashions in alcohol
consumption by the market and consumers responding to trends and fashions?  Are
there discernible patterns which the Government might use in responding to the
effects of alcohol misuse?  Is there useful evidence we might draw on?
Of particular concern, is the current trend of targeting the younger drinkers with alco-pops
and shots.  These are deliberately marketed to appeal to the younger drinkers as they look
attractive and taste of fruit juices.  They encourage a culture of excessive drinking by the
younger more vulnerable age group who would not normally drink spirits.
C:\TEMP\Draft Let for ACC(O) re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy      13.01.03.docAn example of this trend was evident at a recent “life skills” event involving 10 and 11
year old school children.  They were shown a selection of alco-pops and most were able to
identify all of them by name and brand and indicated that they have tried them for
themselves at home.
53 How far do you foresee research and development creating innovative market-led
solutions to the problems of alcohol misuse?
In the future there will probably be some medical prescription to stop obesity, which could
be caused by excess beer drinking.  There will also probably be a pill to cure hangovers so
removing the morning after thought “that I will never drink again”.
54 How best can Government work with the alcohol industry to reach consumers?
What approaches have been shown to be effective in England, the devolved
administrations and further afield?
The Government should work closely with the Industry.  Adherence to the Portman Group
Code of Practice should be compulsory not voluntary.
55 Are there other commercial interests which can influence drinking behaviour?
The price and availability of drinks is a major influence.
THE ECONOMIC COSTS AND BENEFITS OF ALCOHOL
(56) to (61) deal with commercial issues and I am unable to reply to these specific
questions.
As a general comment under this heading, maybe there could be an increase to business rates
for alcohol outlets in order to contribute more money to policing costs.  For example shop
like Dorothy Perkins are probably paying the same business rate as a medium size late night
fun pub.  The potential policing problems from Dorothy Perkins are somewhat less than that
for the fun pub and maybe this should be reflected in the rates.
Last year this Force reviewed and produced its own Licensing Strategy document.  It is police
orientated but I have enclosed a copy for your information.
Yours sincerely
ACC(O)
Mr S J PEARCE
C:\TEMP\Draft Let for ACC(O) re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strategy      13.01.03.doc
Draft Let for ACC_O_ re Nat Alcohol Harm Reduction Strateg…

FOREIGN SECRETARY CONDEMNS ATTACKS ON POLICE STATIONS IN IRAQ


(24/06/04)









In response to attacks on police stations in Iraq, on 24 June, the Foreign Secretary said:



'I condemn the horrific attacks on a number of Iraqi police stations which have taken place this morning.  I understand that more than 30 people have been killed in an explosion in Mosul while attacks in Baquba and Ramadi have resulted in the deaths of around another 20 people. Many more Iraqis have been wounded.  My sincere condolences go to the families of the victims.'



'We have long expected that there would be difficult times in the run-up to the hand-over of sovereignty to the Iraqis. These attacks are targeted on those Iraqis who are working hard to build a better future for their country.  They are aimed at depriving the Iraqi people of the peaceful and democratic future they deserve.  They will not succeed. We are giving our full support to the Iraqi Interim Government in their work to establish strong Iraqi security forces and to help prevent similar attacks in the future.'






الترجمة العربية

       Welfare Reform on the Web - September 1999
 
 

HEALTH CARE - OVERSEAS







CLINTON GEARS UP FOR SPENDING BONANZA



M. Kettle


Guardian, June 30th 1999, p. 14


President Clinton has announced a new health prescription benefit
worth up to $2000 a year.  Cumulative budget surpluses over 15
years are expected to yield an influx of tax dollars into the
US Treasury, widening the scope for spending without imposing
fresh tax burdens on middle class voters.


(See also Financial Times, June 30th 1999, p. 7)




DEFENDING SOCIAL AND HEALTH SERVICES UNDER THREAT : QUESTIONS
AND STRATEGIES



L. Levitt,  A. H. Beckerman and P. Johnson


Journal of Social Work Practice, vol. 13, 1999, p. 59-67


Scenarios which envisage an enhanced role for social work in health
care all require an increased knowledge of the workings of the
market and a greater ability on the part of the profession to
participate in the market as a forceful player.  They require
the emergence of the social work profession as an important force
in efforts to reform health care in the US to achieve universal
access, a uniform payment system, and more effective controls
over expenditure.  Health care professions need to develop a political
orientation which recognises the need to organise interdisciplinary
coalitions which share the struggle to protect health and social
services.




A FISTFUL OF DOLLARS



H. Berliner


Health Service Journal, vol. 109, June 17th 1999, p. 28


Reports that lawsuits to reclaim the costs of treating the wounded
from gun manufacturers are the latest development in US litigation.




NATIONAL HEALTH POLICIES : SUB-SAHURAN AFRICAN CASE STUDIES
(1980-1990)



K. Dugbatey


Social Science and Medicine, vol. 49, 1999,  p. 223-249


Four countries, Botswana, Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana and Zimbabwe were
chosen as cases to study the impact of national health policies
on national health status in sub-Shaharan Africa.  Through a conceptual
framework that covers health problem identification, policy formation
and implementation procedures, the study examined national translations
of Primary Health Care (PHC) and Health for All by the Year 2000
(HFA/2000) strategies.  Study concluded that policies formulated
and implemented in accordance with key PHC principles could account
for improvements in national health status.




OBLIGATORY MEDICAL INSURANCE IN RUSSIA : THE PARTICIPANTS'
PERSPECTIVE.



J. L. Twigg


Social Science and Medicine, vol. 49, 1999, p. 371-382


Paper offers a brief description of the parameters of the Russian
medical insurance system introduced in 1993 to raise funds for
health care.  Then presents the results of a survey which asked
managers of the two major new institutional participants in health
care financing, private medical insurance companies and the 89
governmental Territorial Health Insurance Funds, their opinions
of the structural and behavioural aspects of the new system. 
These survey findings illustrate the dynamics of the bureaucratic
and institutional conflict which has led to incomplete and flawed
implementation of the insurance system.




POLITICAL ANALYSIS OF HEALTH REFORM IN THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC



A. Glassman and others


Health Policy and Planning, vol. 14, 1999,  p. 115-126


Article presents a method of political analysis for health sector
politics, and identifies key patterns in the politics of health
reform proposals.  Uses the experience of one country, the Dominican
republic, to illustrate the political challenges of health reform.




PRIVATE HEALTH CARE IN NIGERIA : WALKING THE TIGHTROPE



I. Ogunbekun, A. Ogunbekun and N. Orobaton


Health Policy and Planning, vol. 14, 1999, p. 174-181


The inadequacy of state health care services has made the private
sector an unavoidable choice for consumers of health care in Nigeria.
 However, ineffective state regulation has meant little control
over the clinical activities of private sector providers while
the price of medical services has grown faster than the average
rate of inflation.  Reforms aimed at increasing the efficiency
of the private sector are urgently required if costs are to be
contained.




QUALITY IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS IN HEALTH CARE : PROBLEM SOLVING
IN THE WORKPLACE



E. Gilpatrick


Thousand Oaks, Calif: Sage, 1999.


Book reviews the basic techniques for carrying out quality improvement
research. Then describes how these techniques can be implemented
through 14 case studies involving actual health care situations.
 Written from a US perspective.




RESOURCE DEPENDENCY, DOCTORS AND THE STATE:  QUALITY CONTROL
IN SWEDEN



P. Garpenby


Social Science and Medicine, vol. 49, 1999, p. 405-424


Paper focuses on the interaction between the state and the medical
profession on the national level in Sweden with respect to issues
concerning quality development in health care. The increased politicising
of the issue of health care quality resulted in public organisations
having reason to increase their interaction with professional
associations.  Interest in the resources controlled by the profession
motivated the development of inter-organisational relationships.
 Equally, the professional bodies also needed resources controlled
by the state.




THE ROLE OF THE PRIVATIZATION PROCESS ON TUBERCULOSIS CONTROL
IN HOCHIMINH CITY PROVINCE, VIETNAM



E. Naterop and J. Wolffers


Social Science and Medicine,  vol. 48, 1999, p. 1589-1598


Paper describes the functioning of the National Tuberculosis Program
(NTP)  in the province of HoChiMinh City, and the impact of the
privatisation process.  Problems of double infection with HIV
and TB mean that an integrated strategy for AIDS and tuberculosis
is required.


This would have to include the development of a health education
programme and the training of private practitioners in the treatment
of TB.  Health education is essential for tuberculosis control
but will not be initiated within the private sector.  It is essential
that the NTP and the private sector co-operate in health education
and training initiatives.




THE SPANISH HEALTH CARE SYSTEM : LESSONS FOR NEWLY INDUSTRIALIZED
COUNTRIES.



E. Rodriguez, P. Gallo de Puelles and A. J. Jovell


Health Policy and Planning, vol. 14, 1999,  p. 164-173


Summaries the organisation, financing and delivery of health care
services in Spain, and discusses the elements that made it possible
to maintain high levels of health among the population while spending
comparatively less on the health care system than most industrialised
countries.

title: Mother Clap's Molly House by The Royal National Theatre
text:
Mother Clap's Molly House by The Royal National Theatre
	


	 	Flagrant homosexuality on stage! 
	 
      production:

    	 
      Mother Clap's Molly House

    	[print]
	 
      company:

    	 
      The Royal National Theatre

    
	 
      venue:

    	 
      New Theatre, Cardiff

    
	 
      date:

    	 
      December 5, 2001

    
	 	
	

"The international success of 1996's 'SHOPPING AND FUCKING' brought Mark Ravenhill fame and a reputation as a playwright keen to bring to the stage a celebration of sexual promiscuous, queer generation, fuelled by ecstasy, credit cards and house music. His work has been acclaimed by many, reviled by some, and an entirely predictable outcry met the announcement of 'MOTHER CLAP'S MOLLY HOUSE' and the disclaimer that the play "contains scenes and language which some people may find offensive". DAN REBELLATO 



It seems in the early eighteenth century we were just as mercenary and sexually unrepressed as we are at the beginning of the twenty first century judging by the activities going on in Mother Claps Molly House, a sort of male brothel. 



The sort of thing that went on is described in evidence given by one William Davison at the trial of Thomas Wright for Sodomy in April 1726 - "The discovery of the Molly House was chiefly owing to a quarrel betwixt P and Harrington. P to be revenged on Harrington gave a large information. The Mollies had heard little of the first discovery. I was introduced to the company and in a large room there we found one a-fiddling and eight more a-dancing country dances, making vile motions and singing, ' Come Let Us Fuck Finely'.  Then they sat in one another's laps, talked bawdy and practised great many indecencies". PROGRAMME NOTE 



The play originated as a workshop production presented and commissioned by the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art where a great deal of script development had taken place. 



So a sound provenance. What has it given us? A literary forward looking piece of worthwhile and challenging new drama or a self-indulgent celebration of gay promiscuity? Maybe I'm a coward but I'm ducking this issue. When the play starts its West End run at the Aldwych Theatre the public will make their own judgement. 



Director Nicholas Hytner has brought together an interesting range of contrasting physical shapes in his wonderful ensemble cast. As a piece of animated sculpture apart from early slow bits the productions sweeps marvellously through its two hours and Giles Cadle's wonderful set gives it all a spectacular frame work. The 'artful' way in which the play move back and forth between the eighteenth century and modern times is fascinating and works in a very smooth and attractive manner. 



I am sure that within the play there lies many statements of social significance, some made during the four examples of homosexual physical celebration going on right before our eyes, but I can't bring any to mind. The play remains a celebration of its own philosophy and a very real and exciting ground breaking evening in the theatre. 
	reviewer:	Michael Kelligan

RAMMELL SECURES VISIT TO NORTH KOREAN BLAST SITE


(14/09/04)









During his 3-day visit to North Korea, Foreign Office Minister Bill Rammell brokered movement on human rights and urged the regime to commit fully to the next round of the regional six-party nuclear talks.



Speaking today from the North Korean capital Pyongyang, Mr Rammell said:



'The visit has certainly broken new ground in our relations with North Korea.  All of my meetings carried the same message: that the UK is ready to engage in a full and proper relationship with North Korea once the concerns of the international community, on issues such as nuclear programmes and human rights, have been addressed.'



'The regime has indicated a willingness to engage with us.  The fact that they agreed to participate for the first time in a serious discussion on human rights is a welcome and positive step.  I also pressed hard for a firm commitment to the nuclear talks process, which they agreed to in principle.  But they need to do more in committing to a date for the next round of talks.  I was genuinely pleased that, following my representation about the reports of an alleged nuclear explosion in North Korea, the Foreign Minister was able to provide an early explanation and agreed to a visit to the site by the British Ambassador and diplomats from other countries.  This is a small but significant concession given the secretive nature of the regime.'



'The visit has been very constructive but we still have a long way to go in developing a proper relationship.  The choice rests with the North Koreans.  Real engagement would lead to huge benefits for the country and its people.  Continued isolation will only bring further problems for North Korea.'

'IRAN, IRAQ AND THE UNITED STATES'


(12/11/03)









EDITED TRANSCRIPT OF AN INTERVIEW GIVEN BY THE FOREIGN SECRETARY, JACK STRAW, TO BBC RADIO 4, WEDNESDAY 12 NOVEMBER 2003


QUESTION:

The Foreign Secretary Jack Straw is going to Washington today, he will talk about Iraq obviously there is a lot to talk about.  Not least that Paul Bremer, the man who runs the country for the Americans has been called back for urgent talks at the Whitehouse.  There is also Iran, who have been forced to admit that they have been producing plutonium and enriched uranium even though they have denied it for eighteen years.  You would only want that sort of stuff if you wanted to make a bomb.  The American Secretary of State Colin Powell said Iran had dragged the scared garments of Islam in to the political gutter.  Well on the line is Jack Straw, the Foreign Secretary.  How do you think we should be dealing with Iran?


JACK STRAW:

We should be reacting calmly to the latest report from the International Atomic Energy Agency.  The Iranians have been concealing activities for many years, which they should have disclosed under the terms of the Non-proliferation Treaty.  Since the IAEA board however, passed a very tough resolution by thirty five votes to one (the only one being Iran) on 12 September Doctor Al Baradei is reporting a considerable degree of co-operation by the Iranians.  And this report which is certainly very worrying in terms of what it discloses, also shows a pretty high level of co-operation.  I can't say whether the co-operation has been complete but it has certainly been substantial.  The next stage is that the report will be considered by the IAEA board on 20 November, in just over a week's time and in the meantime there will be discussions with all our partners about what approach we should take.  And certainly from the UK position, what I want to do about it is to ensure that it is resolved peacefully, quickly and within the terms of international treaties to which Iran and the rest of us are signed up.


QUESTION:

The point about this is that Iran has been even more badly than Iraq in the sense that we now have evidence that they were actively pursuing a nuclear programme.  And again there was no evidence that Iraq was an active state sponsor of terrorism.  Why is our reaction to Iran so very different to our reaction to Iraq?


JACK STRAW:

Well in principle I don't think it is.  We took military action in respect of Iraq twelve years after Iraq invaded Kuwait and after resolution 678 and then 687 was passed saying that Iraq posed a threat to international peace and security.  And also authorising all necessary means which means military action in respect of Iraq.


QUESTION:

So why don't we go to the United Nations now and say we should do the same to Iran?


JACK STRAW:

Because we have to pursue these matters patiently and by diplomatic means.  Now there are no chapter seven resolutions in respect of Iran whereas there were a whole host of them in respect of Iraq.  And what I was making clear repeatedly on your programme as well as in many other places during the run up to military action in respect of Iraq, was that we wanted a diplomatic solution to the situation in Iraq.  And the international community had sought that solution to the problems in Iraq over the period not of twelve months but of twelve years.  Now you say that the transgressions by Iran are more serious than those by Iraq, I beg to differ.  There is no evidence of large scale active chemical, biological and nuclear weapons programmes on the scale which were disclosed and were discovered having been clandestinely hidden by the Iraqis in the mid 1990s.


QUESTION:

So well hidden that we still haven't found them.


JACK STRAW:

With great respect they were found and they were found only after defections by Iraqis and not by inspections and they were concealing those under the noses of inspectors.


QUESTION:

But here we have Colin Powell saying the Iranian regime has dragged the sacred garments of Islam in to the political gutter.  Now we are the closest ally of the United States but we seem to be taking a very different view indeed of what he is saying about Iran.


JACK STRAW:

Well this allows me to make another point because we are either the poodles of the United States or, when we actually have a slightly different opinion from the United States, we are divided.  What we have are some differences of emphasis.  We are all agreed about the obligations which should be imposed on Iran and we all agreed the resolution that came before the IAEA board on 12 September.  There are different analyses about Iran because of the history between Iran and the United States and the issue of Iran and America is felt more sensitively than it is in Europe.  Now we have different analyses but we share a common objective.  We want first of all to see Iran fully and completely complying with its international obligations.  And we want to see a process by which Iran comes fully in to the democratic modern fold while having and being able to show full respect to its Islamic roots and to the fact that is an Islamic Republic.


QUESTION:

You've said twice before on this programme that that the idea of attacking Iran is not on the agenda at all and will not be.  But if Mr Powell says we must go down the sanctions road, will you support him?


JACK STRAW:

First of all you are right to quote me twice on the programme, I am happy to repeat it a third time, just to say that there is no kite flying on that one.  It is a matter for the IAEA board to decide whether or not the matter should be referred to the Security Council and in what circumstances.  Now I am not going to pre-empt the decisions of the IAEA board taking place in about nine days time.  We will be discussing with our international partners and in particular as well the discussions which I will be holding with Secretary Powell.  I will also be discussing this matter in great detail with Dominic De Villepin and Joschkar Fischer, the French and German foreign ministers with whom I made the very important visit to Tehran on 20 October.


QUESTION:

Can I turn to Iraq?  Paul Bremer has been called back to Washington for talks at the Whitehouse, crisis talks some would say.  What do you want to see?  What do you believe will come out of those talks and what do want to see come out of those talks?


JACK STRAW:

Well it is not surprising that there is continuing discussion between Paul Bremer, the head of the Coalition Commission Authority and the administration.  I am not party to the talks nor a party to his return visit but what has been happening obviously the security situation is unsatisfactory and that is well known.


QUESTION:

It is disastrous isn't it?


JACK STRAW:

Well it is unsatisfactory and in particular in Baghdad and the Sunni triangle, but elsewhere including in the South where we are in control, it is satisfactory in general.  And I should also say that over all much else in terms of life in Iraq is now better than it was before the military action commenced.  So there are two issues which are under serious discussion at the moment.  One is the issue of how you improve the security and that is a matter which was discussed between the United Kingdom government and General Myers and General Zabazaid when they were here last week.  The second is how do you create a greater dynamic in the political process in order to see what we all want to happen as soon as possible, namely a transfer of power and sovereignty to the Iraqi people?  We are all agreed about that and resolution 1511 in the Security Council said that it should happen as quickly as possible, the question is how?  And what you have to do is to keep that constantly under review.  Up to now the view has been you make the governing council the agent of that process, but there have also been suggestions, not just from the United States and ourselves but from our other partners, that there may be other ways of achieving that.  The analogy used on your programme earlier this morning was the Afghanistan model, all of those matters need to be looked at because there is this deadline of 15 December which has been set by the United Nations by which more detailed plans have to be produced.


QUESTION:

How do you react to the comments from the Iraqi foreign minister in an interview he did for the Financial Times in which he talked about American in-fighting and blamed geriatric ambassadors, taken to be a reference to our own Sir Jeremy Greenstock?


JACK STRAW:

Look there have been a lot of discussions about what to do in Iraq because this issue is difficult, the more difficult the issues are the more detailed discussions you have.  But both discussions are taking place in Washington, in London and in Baghdad, they will continue.  Going back six months, people said that Iraq would be ungovernable, that we wouldn't get the hospitals, the schools, the water supply going, we wouldn't be able to have a currency transfer, we wouldn't get the economy going.  All of those things have happened.


QUESTION:

But as you say, all over shadowed by the security situation, something has got to be done about that.  Is the way to deal with it to hand over power to the Iraqi people very much more quickly than had been planned even if it is only an appointed government?


JACK STRAW:

We want to hand over power to the Iraqi people as quickly as possible and it could well be that we hand over power to the Iraqis more quickly than planned.  However, we as the coalition have clear responsibilities for security in Iraq.  So we want to see this process happen as quickly as we can.  But it also has to happen in a responsible way where those who are receiving the power or the partial transfer of power can also be assured that there are sufficient facilities and arrangements in place for the better security of Iraq.  Now we are making progress on that, the numbers of police are going to rise, it is going to rise from forty thousand to seventy thousand, we are very heavily involved in training the police numbers in the Iraqi civil defence force and the static guarding forces are rising.  And you have seen for example far fewer examples of sabotage of major infrastructure in Iraq partly as a result.  But yes, we want to move ahead as quickly as possible but also in the context of better security and assurances about security for the Iraqi people.


QUESTION:

George Bush is coming to this country next week.  Who agreed that it should be a state visit?  Who recommended it and why?


JACK STRAW:

The decision was made seventeen months ago by the Royal Visits Committee and then, which is a committee which is based principally of members of the Royal household and the Foreign Office with other government departments.


QUESTION:

The Royal household just does what it is told by the Foreign Office.


JACK STRAW:

Well it is a process of discussion and then the decisions are that the recommendations from the Royal Visits Committee go to Ministers including myself, other Cabinet Ministers and the Prime Minister.  It was agreed a long time ago and personally I think it is a very good idea. It is always the case that at least once during a President's term of office there is a large scale visit.  But if this was a visit by which President Bush was a guest of government, which for practical purposes, not for formal purposes, amounts to the same thing, you would be asking me all the same questions.  And there would be speculation about demonstrations in the newspapers in exactly the same way.


QUESTION:

Does it bother you that he is going to use the visit so we are told, for political purposes back in the United States?  And it doesn't bother you that half the British public according to a Times poll yesterday, regard Mr Blair's closeness to Mr Bush as bad for Britain?


JACK STRAW:

What bothers me is the fashionable anti Americanism that is around.


QUESTION:

Why is it fashionable?


JACK STRAW:

Because many more people I guess will be demonstrating about the United States and the action that the United States has had to take since 11 September.  Never have they demonstrated against the brutal, vicious, horrible regime of Saddam Hussein which has lead as we now know following the liberation of Iraq, to the discovery of mass graves which sadly are the graves of at least three hundred thousand dead souls in Iraq.  Now people are entitled to demonstrate but what I hope will come from this visit and consideration about this visit is a mature reflection on the nature of our relationship with the United States and with Europe and its importance.  And yes, there are issues on which we sometimes disagree as we do for example on steel tariffs or on climate change.  There are issues sometimes where you may have a slightly different analysis as we do in respect in respect for example of the Middle East or in respect as you were talking about, the IAEA report.  Not a great deal but something, there are other issues over all on which we agree profoundly.  America is our largest trading, trading partner by far, huge numbers of jobs on both sides of the Atlantic depend on that relationship.  But above all what people have to decide is whether it is better in our interests and that of European countries for America to be pushed away from Europe and the United Kingdom, to become more and more isolated or whether we engage in a constructive partnership with the United States respecting them for what they are?  Which happens to be the oldest and one of the largest democracies in the world and a great force much more for good than many people are willing to concede.

text:
Foreign & Commonwealth Office Country Profiles















Back to Full Graphics







































































	
















BASIC INFORMATION



Full Country Name: The Lao People's Democratic Republic















































































	









Area: 236,800 sq km (91,400 sq mi)

Population: 5.5m (2002 estimate)

Capital City:  Vientiane (319,000 approx.)

People: Lao (52.5%), Phuthai (10.5%), Khmu (11%), Hmong (6.9%).  Official total is 47 ethnic groups.

Languages: Lao

Religion(s): The population is 65.4% Buddhist, with 33.1% animist, 1.3 % Christian and 0.1% Other, including a tiny Islamic minority (1995 census).

Currency: Kip

Major political parties: Lao People's Revolutionary Party  (Leader: Khamtay Siphandone)

Government: One-party Republic

Head of State: Khamtay Siphandone

Prime Minister/Premier: Bounnyang Vorachit

Foreign Minister: Somsavath Lengsavath (also a Deputy Prime Minister)

Membership of international groupings/organisations: Laos is a member of the United Nations (UN), Non Aligned Movement (NAM), Group of 77 at the United Nations (G77), Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the Asia-Europe Meeting (ASEM).

(Note on Lao Names: Lao people generally have two names, the first being the given name and the second the family name. Nevertheless, if only one name is used, it should be the first, eg. President Khamtay.)
GEOGRAPHY

Laos is a land-locked country, bounded by China, Vietnam, Cambodia, Thailand and Burma. It is largely mountainous.  The most fertile land is found in the valley of the Mekong, which flows from the north of Laos to the south and which forms the frontier with Thailand for over 60% of its length.

HISTORY

Recent History

After gaining its independence from France in 1953, the Kingdom of Laos found itself embroiled in regional conflicts resulting from the struggle for control of South Vietnam. The North Vietnamese supported the Pathet Lao, a nationalist front organisation controlled by the communist  Lao People's Revolutionary Party (LPRP). The Thais and the Americans supported right-wing groups.  Prince Souvanna Phouma, Prime Minister for most of the period from 1951 to 1975, attempted to follow a neutral course.

Following the American withdrawal from Vietnam the Lao Communists consolidated their control of Laos, which culminated in the abolition of the monarchy and establishment of the Lao People's Democratic Republic in December 1975.

As the LPRP instituted a one-party state and introduced tough socialist reforms of the economy it continued its hard line policies until economic difficulties in the late 1980s forced it to bring in more liberal measures in line with those being adopted in Vietnam, with which Laos has been closely aligned since 1975.
 
In 1992 Kaysone Phomvihane, the long-time leader of the LPRP, died. He was succeeded as party leader by the then Prime Minister, Khamtay Siphandone. Since then the government and party have cautiously and half-heartedly introduced market reforms, while maintaining tight political control in a one-party system of government.

Longer Historical Perspective

The Lao are one branch of the Tai ethnic group which moved southwards from southern China, settling in parts of present day Laos from at least the thirteenth century.  From its foundation in 1353 until about 1700 the Lao Kingdom of Lane Xang was one of the most powerful states in mainland Southeast Asia and included much of present day Thailand. Thereafter the kingdom was divided into rival principalities and fell into decline, losing power to the expanding Vietnamese and Siamese states.  It was effectively saved from absorption by these two states by the establishment of a French protectorate at the end of the nineteenth century.

Under French rule development in Laos, whether it be economic, educational or political, was slow compared to that in Vietnam and Cambodia, the other countries in French Indochina. A stimulus to political development was provided by the Japanese occupation of Indochina during the Second World War. After the Japanese defeat in August 1945 a Free Lao movement, the Lao Issara, proclaimed Lao independence, but with the support of the King and Crown Prince the French regained control of the country in 1946, driving the nationalists into exile. The French finally granted Lao independence in 1953.




























	









	








BBC Monitoring Timeline











POLITICS

Recent Political Developments

The government celebrated the 25th anniversary of its accession to power in December 2000 without disruption. The seventh congress of the Lao People's Revolutionary Party was held in March 2001, and later that month the National Assembly endorsed a number of changes to the government, including the replacement of Prime Minister Sisavath Keobounphan by Bounnyang Vorachit.

The National Assembly sat most recently in April/May 2003. In addition to the changes in the constitution related to the economy described below, fundamental rights now include the 'right to complain and right to charge'. The Powers of the President were also strengthened. The position now has the power to propose to the National Assembly the appointment or removal of the Prime Minister.

There have been a series of fatal violent incidents in 2004 including bombings and armed attacks on buses. These have occurred in Vientiane and on roads leading from the Capital, in particular Route 13 between Viang Vieng to Luang Prabang and Route 7 between Phoukhon and Phonsavan. Civilians, including two foreign tourists, have been killed and many others injured. It is unclear who is behind these incidents, but Hmong insurgents have been blamed. On 2 October Bouasone Bouphavanh was appointed Deputy Prime Minister responsible for home affairs to tackle mounting tensions.

Elections

The last general elections were held on 24 February 2002 and resulted in many changes in the National Assembly, although only one non-party member was elected. The electoral term is five years.

ECONOMY

Basic Economic Facts

GDP: US$ 1.8 (2002)

GDP per capita: US$328 (2002)

GDP per capita (PPP): US$1,575 (2000)

Annual Growth: 6% (2003 estimate)

Inflation: 8%

Major Sectors: Agriculture (50% of GDP), Services (26%) - wholesale and retail the largest part, of this.  Industry (24%) - garment manufacturing, food processing and low – tech assembly are growth sectors.

Major trading partners: Laos is a net importer and mainly trades with counties of the region. In 2002 the main trading partners were: Vietnam, Thailand, France, Germany, Belgium, China, Singapore , Japan.
 
Aid & development: Aid to Laos in 1998 totalled US$ 281m. Of US$ 165m in bilateral aid, by far the largest donor was Japan, at over US$ 85m.  International organisations working with Laos who have offices in Vientiane include the IMF, World Bank, Asian Development Bank and various UN agencies.

Exchange rate: £1 = 14,200 January 2004)



























	









	








UK Trade & Investment Country Profile: Laos











INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS

Laos' Relations with its Neighbours

Although the Lao people are much more closely related to the Thais than to other neighbours in language and culture, Laos was linked to Vietnam and Cambodia as part of French Indochina from the end of the nineteenth century until independence in 1953. Following an attempt to steer a neutral course, ties with Vietnam and Cambodia were strengthened after the communist victories in all three countries in 1975. Relations with the strongly anti-Communist governments of Thailand were difficult. In the aftermath of the Sino-Vietnamese rift of the late 1970s and 1980s, Laos' relations with China were also strained.

As the general situation in mainland Southeast Asia improved in the 1980s and early 1990s with a decrease in ideological alignments and progress towards a solution of the divisive Cambodian problem, Laos was able significantly to improve ties with other countries in the region. The first bridge across the Mekong River between Thailand and Laos was opened in April 1994.  In November 1994 the Mekong River Commission was established – involving Laos, Cambodia, Thailand and Vietnam - whose principle objective is the sustainable utilisation of the Mekong Basin. Laos joined ASEAN in July 1997.

Laos' Relations with the International Community

Laos is currently chair of ASEAN and will host the Summit meeting in Vientiane on 29 November 2004. Laos co-chaired with Greece the EU/ASEAN Foreign Ministers meeting in January 2003 in Brussels.  The EU Commission opened an office in Laos in May 2003.  Laos joined ASEM in October 2004.

LAOS' RELATIONS WITH THE UK

Diplomatic Representation

The first resident British Ambassador arrived in Laos in the mid-1950s.  The Embassy was closed in 1985, and responsibility for British representation to Laos passed to the British Ambassador in Bangkok, who manages the British Trade Office (BTO) in Laos. The current British Ambassador to the Lao People's Democratic Republic is His Excellency Mr David Fall. He arrived in Thailand in August 2003. The BTO opened in Vientiane in 1995, and covers trade issues and development work. Current relations with Laos are friendly if limited.

The Laos, similarly, had an Embassy in London from the 1950s until it was closed in the mid-1980s. The current Lao Ambassador in Paris, His Excellency Mr Soutsakhone Pathammavong is accredited to the UK.

Ambassade de la Republique Democratique Populaire Lao

UK overseas mission in Laos
The UK played an important diplomatic role in Laos as Co-Chairman (along with the former USSR) of the 1954 Geneva Conference on Indo-China and the 1961/2 Geneva Conference on Laos.

UK Development Assistance

The Department for International Development (DfID) does not have a bilateral aid programme for Laos. However small scale UK assistance is provided through the Small Grant Scheme (administered by the British Trade Office in Vientiane and the British Embassy in Bangkok), the DfID Civil Society Challenge Fund, and support for individual projects under Foreign and Commonwealth Office programme budgets.

A UK project to introduce a nationwide system of Childrens Justice by 2006 is well under way as the National Assembly announced in October that a draft bill would be prepared by the end of the 2004. The project, which started as a pilot in 2000, began full implementation in 2001. The initiative is undertaken by the Ministry of Justice with technical support from Save the Children and financial support from the FCO Human Rights Project Fund. The project delivers training to judges, prosecutors, police officers and local officials on principles of children's rights and juvenile justice. This leads on to reforms to the local justice system which divert children from the formal justice system, promote non-custodial sentencing, establish specialist youth courts, and resolve cases through village mediation using principles of restorative justice. So far the project has reached half of all provinces in the country and trained more than 2500 officials.

In 2001-2003 Small Grant Scheme support was given to projects relating to HIV/AIDS and malaria.  Other assistance was provided to rural development, education, human rights, mine/UXO clearance and drug control.
 
Trade and Investment with the UK

Bilateral trade between the UK and Laos accounts for only a small portion of UK trade with SE Asia.  Imports from Laos in 2002 were worth £10.1 million (up 41.8% on 2001 - £7.1 million). UK exports to Laos in 2002 were £1.6 million (down 32% on 2001 - £2.3 million). The UK's top exports to Laos include general industrial machinery and equipment, and telecommunications. The UK's top imports from Laos include apparel and clothing accessories, and footwear.

Cultural Relations with the UK

Cultural links are relatively limited in nature. However in 2001 the David Glass Interactive Theatre Group worked with the Lao Women's Union to stage a number of performances in Vientiane with the theme of raising awareness of HIV/AIDS and drug issues.

The number of British visitors to Laos has increased over recent years, numbering 15,700 in 2001. This is second only to France in terms of visitors from Europe.

Recent Visits

In the margins of the EU/ASEAN Ministerial meeting in Vientiane in 2000 the Foreign Office Minister John Battle met Lao Foreign Minister, Somsavat Lengsavat. Foreign Office Minister Derek Fatchett also met the Lao Foreign Minister in the margins of the ASEAN Post Ministerial Conference in Kuala Lumpur in July 1997.

Inward

	Aug 1999: Soubanh Srithirath, Minister in the President's Office and Chairman of the Lao National Commission on Drug Control

	Jun 2001: Phongsavath Boupha, Deputy Foreign Minister

	Jan 2003: Sayakane Sisouvong, Director General, ASEAN Department. Ministry of Foreign Affairs 


Outward

	1987: The Princess Royal to visit Save the Children Fund (UK)

	Dec 2000: Mr Battle, Minister of State, FCO, for an EU/ASEAN meeting


HUMAN RIGHTS

The human rights situation in Laos has improved over the last decade, but some issues still arouse concern, particularly the treatment of a small number of political prisoners and Christian activists.  The most prominent political prisoners are Latsami Khamphoui and Feng Sakchittaphong. Thongsouk Saysangkhi, a third prisoner, died in prison in 1998.  The three were arrested in October 1990 and held without charge for two years.  In 1992 they were sentenced to 14 years in prison for forming a 'social democrat club' to advance democratic ideas.  The defendants were not permitted legal representation at their trial and the sentence was harsh.  The UK, along with EU partners, has raised its concern about these cases with the Lao authorities.

Five protestors, Thongpaseuth Keuakoun, Khamphouvieng Sisaath, Seng-Aloun Phengphanh, Keochay and Bouavanh Chanmanivong, were arrested in Vientiane on 26 October 1999 and sentenced to prison terms believed to be for 10 years, apparently for attempting to stage a political protest. Sentences on two of the five, we understand, have since been reduced from 10 to 5 years. The EU has raised its concerns about the five with the Lao authorities. There are reports of harassment of Christians by the Lao authorities, who appear to object to active proselytising by some groups rather than to the right of peaceful worship, which is recognised by the Lao Constitution. Another cause for concern is the alleged mistreatment of the ethnic Hmong people in Laos. Amnesty International have reported continuing government clashes with Hmong insurgents and forced relocation of Hmong villages. The UK regularly raises these issues with the Lao government when opportunities arise.
 
Laos has long held a de facto moratorium on the death penalty. But in April 2001 the scope of
application of the death penalty was extended to drug related crimes at the urging of ASEAN partners. Three individuals were sentenced to death by the Vientiane Municipality Court on 19th June 2002. We understand that one individual has now had his sentence reduced to 25 years and further appeals are pending on the other two.  The EU has urged Laos to maintain its de facto moratorium on the death penalty.

HEALTH

The average life expectancy at birth is 52.3 years for men and 54.8 years for women. This compares to 67.3 years for men and 73.2 years for women in neighbouring Thailand. It is estimated that 14,000 people die from malaria each year.  Rates of HIV/AIDS infection are slowly increasing. Around 120 people die each year as a result of ordnance explosions.

TRAVEL

Travel Advice: Laos
Last reviewed - 22 October 2004
Foreign & Commonwealth Office Country Profiles

title: Asylum centre upgrade planned
text:
Asylum centre upgrade planned
	
		



	
	
	

	Asylum centre upgrade planned

Campsfield House immigration centre near Oxford is to be modernised and expanded, the Home Office announced today. 

The number of spaces at the centre, which holds single males, could rise from 184 to 290 under the plans. The former young offenders institution had previously been earmarked for closure. 

The Home Office will shortly be seeking planning approval from Cherwell District Council to start the project.

Home Office Minister Beverley Hughes said the UK is removing more failed asylum seekers than ever.

"Immigration removal centres are a key part of our ability to remove from the country those who have no right to be here and ensure an effective end-to-end asylum process. 

"We are expanding the number of spaces in the removals estate, and are looking at a number of options to do so as cost-effectively and efficiently as possible. As part of this we have decided to retain Campsfield House and to maximise the potential of the site by expanding the centre."

	 


		
	
E-mail Tony Blair
Send your views about this news item or any other matter to the Prime Minister.




	
	
	Asylum centre upgrade planned
Asylum centre upgrade planned

text:
Royal Navy: Sea Harrier
