				You are in:

					
	
					Fleet Air Arm
		Sea Harrier

				
	


								

				

								

			
					
					
					
	
			
	

  	
        

        Sea Harrier FA2

        

        The FA2 is a single seat multi-role day/night all-weather aircraft, whose roles in Air Defence and Surface Attack are interchangeable according to the tactical requirement. It is the only true multi-role jet aircraft in service in the UK inventory. Optimised for operations from ships at sea, it's short take-off and vertical landing capability has dramatically enhanced the ability of the Invincible class of Aircraft Carriers to project air power in support of UK interests worldwide.



The FA2 (Fighter Attack) is a development of its predecessor the Sea Harrier FRS1 (Fighter/ Reconnaissance/Strike) concentrating on the avionics and weapons system of the aircraft giving it a much improved air-to-air combat capability, essential to its main task of providing a carrier group with air defence. The Blue Vixen radar coupled with the medium range AIM-120 AMRAAM missile gives the FA2 the ability to engage hostile aircraft before they come into visual range.  Although the main task of the FA2 was air defence it had the capability to be used in the ground attack role, however, the GR7/GR9 would be the first choice of aircraft for this type of mission.

      




	
        Sea Harrier
        FA2 Aircraft Specifications

      


    

	Length	14m
	Engine	A single Rolls Royce Pegasus vectored
        thrust turbofan. Static thrust 21,500lb.
	Weapons	AMRAAM Air to Air Missiles

        Sidewinder Air to Air Missiles

        2 x 30mm Cannons
        Bombs (including 1000lb, 540lb and LGB)

        Self Defence chaff and flares

        Reconnaissance camera

	Radar	Ferranti "Blue Vixen"
        track-while-scan, multi-mode, Pulse Doppler
	Speed	600kts
	Endurance	1hr 30mins (on Combat Air Patrol (CAP)
        100nm from Aircraft Carrier)


	
        

        The Future

        

        On the 28th February 2002, the Armed Forces Minster Adam Ingram announced that the Joint Harrier Force will become an all ground attack harrier force upgrading the Royal Air Force GR7s to GR9s and retiring the Royal Navy FA2s.  This is to ?ensure a credible expeditionary offensive capability is maintained until the aircraft leaves service. Supporting this decision the Ministry of Defence said:



"These days we don't fight the kind of wars where our ships need defending from enemy warplanes far out at sea. Aircraft Carriers are now mostly supporting shore operations by flying strike missions and it makes far better sense to spend our money on Harriers which can do that best. If necessary, we can rely on coalition forces to provide the outer air defence for surface ships."



An added level to the layered air defence will be provided by the new  Type 45 Destroyer  equipped with the sophisticated and lethal Principal Anti Air Missile System (PAAMS) which is capable of controlling several missiles in the air at any one time, each one of which could engage individual targets, preventing attackers from swamping the fleet's air defences.



It is intended that the Harrier force be completely replaced by the  Future Joint Combat Aircraft (FJCA)  also referred to as the Joint Strike Fighter which is due to enter service in 2012 and be operated from the Royal Navy?s  Future Aircraft Carriers (CVF).

UN MEETING FOR SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT OF SMALL ISLAND DEVELOPING STATES


(10/01/05)


Start Date: 10/01/05


End Date: 14/01/05



Location: Port-Louis, Mauritius








	








Mauritius is to host the United Nations International Meeting to Review the Implementation of the Programme of Action for the Sustainable Development of Small Island Developing States (SIDS). The meeting is set to take place from 10 to 14 January 2005.



This is to be an international meeting for the 10-Year Review of the Barbados Programme of Action for the Sustainable Development of the Small Island Developing States.



For the forty-plus small island nations, the Mauritius meeting has big stakes, as they tackle serious threats and seek ways to boost and support their efforts to achieve sustainable development and to improve their inhabitants' lives.

Young Professional: Jozef Polacek




















	










Name: Jozef Polacek

Country: Slovakia

Current Job Title: TV Producer

Employer/Organisation: KUUL KULT Production Company



Biography:

I was born on 6 June in 1970, raised in a family of technical engineer and teacher of biology. Have two brothers, Martin is an archeologist and George is a student of history. In 1999 I finished my University studies of Economy and Business. Since 1984 I was a club dj. In 1993 I started my radio presenting career. In 1996 I joined the first commercial TV in Slovak market – TV Markiza. Used to be presenter of music programs : DEKA HITY (weekly chart of top ten videos), London Calling  (UK chart). In 2001 I started my production company KUUL KULT which is producing five hours of TV programs weekly – focused on music, life style, culture, young people. Beside that I´m producing the biggest dance event in Slovakia – DISCO TV in co-operation with TV Markiza and MTV Europe.



Professional Objectives:

New experience, knowledge, ideas, new friends, contacts. The opportunity of taking part in this program is a great satisfaction for me because a long time ago I started to believe in an idea of one world, one nation and one love and a world without borders.

title: Royal Navy
text:
Royal Navy


	
Tue  9 Nov 2004

ON BOARD SHIP






	
	

	Waste Disposal


 

Plastic Waste 

It is illegal to discharge plastic waste anywhere at sea. A machine is used to compact and seal all plastic waste. This is then taken to shore in the UK for environmentally sound disposal. 



Garbage 

Garbage is classified as waste such as paper, cardboard, glass, tins etc. A garbage-processing unit deals with this by taking all kinds of unsorted waste and shredding and compacting it.
The compacted waste is then stored on board for later disposal ashore.





Food Waste 

Uneaten food is processed through a food pulper, this grinds the waste up into slurry that can be safely discharged at sea when more than 3 miles from land. The Royal Navy is now introducing new generation food pulpers that recycle the water used and produce a “dry” waste that can be stored for later disposal. 



Sewage Treatment Plant 

Most current warships operate a "Biological Sewage Treatment Plant". In the plant, natural bacterial breakdown of the sewage is assisted by clever recirculation of fluids, resulting in the discharge of a clean, clear and environmentally benign effluent.

 

Oil and Oily Waste 

The discharge of oil at sea is illegal and is regulated by the International Maritime Organisation. All the Royal Navy warships are fitted with oil management systems to ensure against unwanted discharge of oil. 



Water and other liquids used in various processes on board RN ships is collected in tanks near the bottom of the ship and is known as "bilge water". Bilge Water cannot be discharged directly into the sea as it may contain oil and other harmful substances, such as detergents. 



This "water" is circulated through Wastewater Treatment Machines, which clean it by either using an oil water separator, membrane filtration or both. The resulting cleaned and filtered water is then checked to ensure that it is safe to be discharged. 



Membranes act as a filter, allowing molecules or particles of a certain size to pass through, whilst retaining the larger ones. They are typically tubular of flat sheets and are made from polymers or ceramics.

 

Oil Water Separator Units consist of a vertical settling tank that allows free-floating oil to be skimmed off the surface of the liquid and disposed of or sent for recycling.

 

The separate module of stainless steel columns, housing tubular ceramic membranes, allows the remaining liquid to be passed through the membranes to remove emulsified oil and other contaminants. This process is known as cross-flow micro-filtration.

title: news story | Brith Gof respond | from the Theatre in Wales web site
text:
news story | Brith Gof respond | from the Theatre in Wales web site
	






	   
      
        
      
      	 
      Brith Gof respond

    
	  

    	
	
	To Mike Baker

I am writing in response to the Draft Drama Strategy for Wales Consultation Paper with reference to Brith Gof.



Obviously we are disappointed that Council has made a provisional decision to fund the company for only six months of 1999 / 2000, and hope that when Council meet on 19 March they will reconsider.



We strongly believe that as an institution, as a body of work and group of artists, and as a company committed to innovation in Welsh language culture, Brith Gof deserves support and should be part of the strategy. 



The Draft Strategy Document proposes to support innovation through project funding. We strongly believe that dependence on project funding is unsustainable for any company, our selves included, and the withdrawal of revenue funding from Brith Gof will therefore end Brith Gof's work in live performance in Wales.



In addition to which, none of the exciting and innovative applications for project funding put forward independently by any of the artists associated with Brith Gof, (Mike Pearson, Mike Brookes, Marc Rees, Sioned Hughes, Eddie Ladd), have received support.



The Draft Strategy confirms Council's commitment to ensuring full diversity of provision in both the languages of Wales. By both withdrawing funding from Brith Gof and failing to fund any of the artists listed above, or indeed proposing a franchise for work of this nature, Council are failing to deliver on their stated commitment.



We believe this clearly illustrates the limitations of a 'projects only' strategy. The Draft Strategy clearly concentrates resources within North and North East Wales. Brith Gof is one of the few companies regularly working in rural West Wales, and one of the very few companies in recent years to have had productions commissioned by promoters in Swansea, the valleys, and West Wales. 



As such, Brith Gof is one of the few cultural institutions in Wales in a position to forge strategic alliances with other education and cultural providers, and take full advantage of the imminent arrival of Objective I status for much of South and West Wales.



International contact and export success cannot be achieved overnight. To loose institutions such as Brith Gof will throw away eighteen years of investment in cultural relations. The role of the arts in promoting Wales internationally and in cultural and economic regeneration will both be important considerations in the coming decade. 



Council needs to rethink the means by which it achieves its priorities. Brith Gof can continue play a significant strategic role in delivering Council's objectives





--------------------------------------------------------------------------------



To: Jo Weston Chief Executive Arts Council of Wales

I am writing in response to the Draft Drama Strategy for Wales Consultation Paper.



I have separately written to Mike Baker with reference specifically to Brith Gof. 



The following are the main points I wished to make. 



1. The consultation process.

Although the consultation process began last year, the consultation period available for discussion of the Draft Drama Strategy is only roughly five weeks. Given that the strategy recommends very significant change I believe that five weeks is totally inadequate.

Moreover, the timing of publication and consultation comes so close to the end of the financial year that, regardless of specific funding decisions, all clients will find it impossible to properly plan for 1999 - 2000.

I am also both surprised and disappointed that the Arts Council of Wales apparently feels it unnecessary to engage in public debate within this current consultation period.

As far as I am aware, none of the companies mentioned within the strategy have been directly consulted as to the viability or desirability of the proposed changes in relation to themselves.

Brith Gof were not consulted as to whether six months of funding is an appropriate level of within which to achieve anything. No indication has been given as to why the work of a particular company does or does not fall within the strategy, why a particular company will or will not be funded in the future.





2. Geography.

I have always understood that a fundamental principle of Arts Council funding is to ensure a good geographic distribution of resources. This principle appears to have been abandoned. The strategy appears to offer nothing to Swansea, Newport, the valleys, mid or West Wales. Such a geographic imbalance surely is deeply damaging





3. Funding fewer better.

The principle of funding fewer was widely discussed during the consultation period last year, and I, like many, supported the principle. However, I did not envisage that the principle would be used to concentrate resources so heavily within such a small number of clients. In particular, I had assumed, wrongly as it appears, that funding for different categories of activity would remain relatively constant. 

The strategy proposes a net reduction in funding to Theatre In Education, to Community Touring Theatre, to Experimental Theatre. It appears that everyone and every sector will suffer to in order to increase support to two newly expanded companies. For many, their only contact with professional live performance is through the work of TIE and Community Touring companies. To effectively deprive this audience of access to professional theatre is both culturally indefensible can only mitigate against the achievement of long term strategic aims; the development of new audiences, and the increasing importance of the arts within the wider cultural life of the nation.

Experimental practise has been rightly compared to research and development within industry. A net reduction in funding to experimental companies, a reduced commitment to support for innovative and artistically and culturally challenging work will inevitably be deeply damaging within wider cultural debate and artistic practise. 

I am truly appalled that the proposal to withdraw funding from Brith Gof is not accompanied by a commitment to revenue fund another Welsh language experimental company. 

The suggestion that revenue support for experimental work will be given to an English language company only clearly contradicts the strategy's stated aim of ensuring diversity across both the languages of Wales.

Given however that this has been proposed, why is the proposed grant increase for Volcano less than that currently given to Brith Gof? Surely, if Brith Gof is to be cut in order to ensure that Volcano can be better supported, Volcano should receive the full value of our grant in addition to their current award. 

The strategy proposes an overall reduction of roughly £70,000 for experimental theatre. 





4. Project Funding.

One of reasons why I have supported the principle of funding fewer better has been to ensure an increased budget for project funding. 

The importance of project funding in supporting the work of independent artists and ensuring the development of new talent is enormous. Project funding is not however, and can never be, a substitute for revenue funding.

The belief that the work of companies such as Brith Gof or Hijinx can continue with project funding is entirely fallacious.





5. Welsh National Performing Arts Companies.

For me, this is the crux of my entire response.

It is from this that the entire strategy has been developed and all funding decisions made. It is clear that the strategy is proposing the creation of a National Theatre of Wales. 

Surely this is a matter for public debate and should rightly be a decision for the Assembly? Surely this is not a proper matter to be decided behind closed doors by a quango.

Intrinsic to that debate is discussion as to the meaning and nature of a national theatre both now and in Wales, the role such an institution could / should play within the cultural life of the nation, and whether indeed the creation of such an institution is of value and benefit.

Debate would therefore naturally broaden into the development of a cultural vision for Wales. Unless such a debate takes place and such a vision is clearly articulated, I fail to see how we can hope to develop an effective and coherent strategy according to which funding priorities can be set and individual funding decisions made.

The strategy fails to articulate such a vision. 

Given everything I have listed above, I am sure you will not be surprised when I say I sincerely hope that Council will decide to reject the Draft Drama Strategy when it meets on March 19th. 



 
	source:

    	 Brith Gof   

      web site: 
	 
      news written 
        by:

    	Alison Woods 
      
      

      e-mail:  
      
      
	 
      first posted 
        

    	Thursday, February 25, 1999

Botulism






Botulism is caused by botulinum toxin, which is a poison produced by the bacterium Clostridium botulinum. In most cases, the symptoms are caused not by the organism itself, but by eating or breathing in the toxin. Botulism cannot be caught from an infected person. 

Symptoms often begin with blurred vision and difficulty in swallowing and speaking, but diarrhoea and vomiting can also occur. The disease can go on to problems with vision, and paralysis. Most cases will recover, but the recovery period can be many months. The disease can be fatal in 5-10% of cases; death is due to respiratory failure. Antitoxin is available which acts as an 'antidote' against the toxin; it must be given as soon as possible for best results.

		Photo Gallery

				
	


								

				

								

			
					
					
					
Photo Gallery


Med deployment



Klaipeda, Lithuanian - Memorial Service 29 May 03
Wreath laying ceremony at Commonwealth War Dead Memorial in Vittener Cemetery by CO and guard of HMS Somerset. The site of the old cemetery is now a memorial park for Private Bunting - 22nd Bn Manchester Regiment who died 13 Dec 1918 aged 33; and private Crockson, 1st Bn Somerset Light Infantry who died 27 Jun 1917 - buried in Szawali (Schaulen) German Cemetary.


Klaipeda Orphanage

25 children from the Rytas Children's Home, Klaipeda (which has 91 children aged 4-19, most of whom will not be adopted) visited HMS Somerset on 30 May 03 for a children's party hosted by the ship's company. The visit was preceded by a press conference, before the party and presentation of some gifts on the flightdeck was made. On 2 Jun 03, 8 members of the ship's company made a return visit to the Rytas Home to deliver the rest of the donations, before continuing on to Giuilari Baby Orphanage in another part of Klaipeda to deliver much needed baby clothes, prams etc. These photographs are for the visit by the ship's company, their families and their friends and filled up a large part of the No2 Naval Store!




Tallinn - Orphanage

A group of ship's company visited the Haiba Children's Home, 40 km from Tallinn, Estonia on 21 May 03 to present some of the children's clothes and toys which had been brought by the ship. Approximately 20 children/supervisors then returned to the ship for a return chidren's party. The CO, Cdr David Barker, also visited the home together with the Logistics & Supply Officer (LSO) Lt Cdr Katja Samuel (who coordinated all of the children's work for the 3 visits) and a female Estonian Naval Officer, Kersti Kelder, who was acting as our translator. The Haiba chidren's home has approximately 40 chidren from 0-17. In all of the chidren's home visits, a light coloured teddy bear can be seen - this was donated to the ship by the Mayor of Bath to take as many photographs as possible of where 'teddy' has been during the deployment as part of her fund raising efforts for the Royal United Hospital in Bath as well as to build a school for orphans in Bangladesh and link a school in Dessie, Ethiopia with a school in Bath.



Riga

In Riga, Latvia, there was a children's party on board for the Ilgas Children's Home (25 May) followed by a return visit the following day (26 May), which also received local media attention (TV and newspapers).


KotorHMS Somerset visiting Kotor, Serbia-Montenegro

You are here: home > downing street > welcome > e-petitions > stamp out stamp duty response







E-petition: stamp out stamp duty campaign
Thank you for your correspondence attaching the Association of Private Client Investment Managers and Stockbrokers (APCIMS) co-ordinated "Stamp Out Stamp Duty" campaign e-petition with collected signatories.
The petition calls for the abolition of stamp duty on share transactions. The Government notes the case APCIMS and others in the financial industry make for this.
Stamp duty on shares is, of course, only one factor in selecting the location for a headquarters company. The UK is one of the most business friendly environments in the world and the benefits of locating in the UK include low rates of corporate and personal taxes and a network of over 100 tax treaties. There is no firm evidence to suggest that stamp duty is causing UK companies involved in overseas mergers to incorporate outside the UK.
The Government does, however, keep all aspects of the tax system under review and is happy to listen to views on this and other issues.

		News
		26 Aug 04

				
	


				Further Pages:

					
	
							Continued


					
	


								

				

								

			
					
					
					
	26 Aug 04




Since the last update Montrose has had her first foreign visit.  Between the 8-13 Jul, HMS Montrose was berthed at the Swedish Quay in Zeebrugge to support Belgian Navy Days. 



Nine ships from six different Navies were represented and as well as the official receptions held by the naval base, many of the Ship’s Company took the opportunity to mix and host other crews from the eclectic collection of sailors in Zeebrugge for the weekend. The Ship was open to the public for 2 days and hosted over 4000 visitors from all over Belgium in what proved to be a very popular event.

 









While the Ship was in Belgium, the Ship’s Company took the opportunity to visit not only the local sights around Zeebrugge but also the many fascinating attractions in the nearby city of Bruges. 



Trips had also been organised by the Belgium Navy to Brussels and probably the most popular visit was to the In Flanders Fields World War I Museum at Ypres.  The highlight of this trip for many was the impressive memorial gate at Menin, where the names of over 54000 servicemen are engraved  – a commemoration to those who were never found. The photograph shows members of HMS Montrose Ship’s Company at the section where the soldiers of The Black Watch are remembered, which is one of the Ships’ affiliated regiments.



Before arriving in Zeebrugge the Ship had a very successful Sea Wolf missile test firing at sea off the south coast of England.  The Sea Wolf missile is HMS Montrose’s primary self defence missile and is capable of intercepting incoming missiles or attack aircraft with deadly accuracy and speed.  Three missiles were fired in total, all of which hit the target (which was towed 5 miles behind an aircraft).  



After that success, and on the passage over to Belgium, in some really awful weather, the Ship’s Company participated in the Sports Relief Red Sock event in the Hangar.  Over 60 personnel rowed a mile for charity and as you can see from the photograph, it soon became very competitive, with OM Cuthill achieving the quickest time of 5mins 31sec.  If that was not enough, that evening Chief Lambert and Leading Physical Trainer Derbyshire hosted the first Montrose Bingo night.  Well supported by the Ship’s Company, the first winners shared a pot of over £200 and many are already buying tickets for what will be a regular event while at sea.

India / Pakistan

















Last updated: 8 October 2004


Aim: The India/Pakistan GCPP strategy aims to contribute towards improving relations between India and Pakistan and reducing the risk of conflict, including nuclear conflict, between them. The strategy is an integral part of UK government efforts to encourage India and Pakistan to work towards a stable and secure South Asia, addressing all their outstanding differences, including over Kashmir.



Proposed Action: The strategy aims to improve relations between India and Pakistan through:



Promoting stability, dialogue, confidence-building measures and co-operation between India and Pakistan: Encouraging contact between leaders and people from both countries and promoting public debate on reducing conflict in the region.



Helping to contribute to conflict reduction and conflict resolution in Kashmir: Supporting those involved in work to alleviate the effects of conflict in Kashmir, on both sides of the Line of Control.



Promoting conflict prevention and peaceful reform in Pakistan: Providing assistance to counter violence and the risk of conflict within Pakistani society.



Promoting harmonious inter-communal relations and reducing the risks of violent internal conflict within India: Building capacity to deal with inter-communal conflict within Indian society, including through training and education projects.



For more information please e-mail south-asia.gcpp.enquiries@fco.gov.uk
Foreign & Commonwealth Office India/Pakistan

title: Honorary Secretary & Treasurer
text:
Honorary Secretary & Treasurer 
 
 
          Honorary Secretary & Treasurer 
          Irish Guards Warrant Officers Club 
          7 Watersplash Court, LONDON COLNEY AL2 1TN 
 
              Telephone:   07773 679747 
 
 
 
 
All Members 
 
MINUTES OF THE IRISH GUARDS WARRANT OFFICERS CLUB FORTY-SEVENTH GENERAL MEETING 
ST
HELD ON FRIDAY 1 NOVEMBER 2002 AT THE SERGEANTS MESS, ALL ARMS DRILL WING, 
PIRBRIGHT, SURREY 
 
Present 
 
Major WE Matthews – Chairman 
Mr J Hunter  Mr R Kirkland  CSM J Donaldson RQMS K Gannaway-Pitts 
Mr O Rice  Capt A Gardner  Mr D Meadows  Mr D O’Leary 
Mr A Chambers  Mr M Kinane  WO2 T Welsh  Mr M Kane  
Capt V McEllin  Mr R Bonner  Mr S Granger  Mr M Daly 
WO1 J Mooney  Mr S Walsh  Capt S Boyd  Mr T Anderson 
Lt Col HF Groves Maj AE Smith  Mr L Maguire  Capt J McFarland 
Capt A Cunningham Capt D Ryan  Mr S Jones  Mr K Browne 
Mr G Shone  Maj J Knowles  Capt M Brennan Mr J Kerr 
Maj P Duffy  Mr J Green  Mr K Robinson  CSM P Gleave 
Mr D Cleary  Mr P Fairnie  Lt Col JFP Faloone Maj J Quinn 
Mr J Rees  CSM S Bennett  Capt S Devitt  Mr S Fearon 
Mr T Gregg  WO1 E Whelan  WO2 J Brennan WO2 P Lavery 
CSM S Nichols  RSM R Wilmont  Mr D Hyde – Hon Secretary & Treasurer 
 
Apoligies 
 
Maj V McLean  Mr S Moffatt  Mr F Montgomery Mr B Edwards 
Maj WA Davis  Mr L Huyton  Mr B Horrigan  Mr D Hemphill 
Mr R Harkness  Mr P Lucas  Mr M Hanna  Mr V Nelson 
Mr C Bowker  Mr B McCarthy  Capt MEJ O’Neill Mr H Copnall 
Mr JM Thompson Mr DC Johnstone Capt T Connor  Mr G McGreevy 
Mr DM Thompson Maj A Bell  Mr T Robinson  Mr J Fay 
Capt JB Officer  Mr M Martin  Mr D Cullen  Mr JW Bradley 
Capt J Lynch  Mr P Hubbock  Mr R Rawson  Mr CP Deane 
Lt Col R Cowap  Maj J Clegg  Mr B Croft   
st
RSM and All Members of the 1 Battalion not present 
 
OPENING ADDRESS 
 
1. The Chairman opened the Meeting by welcoming all present. 
 
MINUTES OF THE PREVIOUS MEETING 
 
2. Copies of the Minutes of the previous Meeting were distributed around the Meeting for Members to 
view. 
 
 
  a. Matters Arising.  Members were reminded of the proposition and discussion surrounding the 
status of Members Guests at the Dinner.  As a result a Committee Meeting was held and 
subsequently a postal Ballot took place to determine if any amendment to the current Rules was 
required.  Of the 154 Ballot Papers sent to Members 77 were returned.  71 chose Option A – No 
 
change to current Rules, 4 chose Option B – personal Guests on payment providing they are Serving 
Officers or Warrant Officers and 2 chose Option C- Personal Guests are not allowed. 
 
  
There being no further matters arising it was Proposed by Mr R Kirkland and Seconded by Mr T Anderson that 
the Minutes be passed and the result of the Ballot be ratified.  This proposition was carried. 
 
ACCOUNTS 
 
3. Copies of the Accounts were distributed around the Meeting and it was Proposed by Capt D Ryan and 
Seconded by Capt V McEllin that they be passed.  This proposition was carried. 
 
ELECTION OF CHAIRMAN 
 
4. It was Proposed by WO1 E Whelan and Seconded by Capt M Brennan that the present incumbent be 
Re-Elected for a further term.  This proposition was carried. 
 
ELECTION OF HONORARY SECRETARY AND TREASURER 
 
5. It was proposed by Mr L Maguire and Seconded by Maj A Smith that the present incumbent be re-
elected for a further term.  This proposition was carried. 
 
ELECTION OF COMMITTEE MEMBERS 
 
6. RSM J Mateer and RQMS K Smith were to be replaced and it was Proposed by Maj J Quinn and 
Seconded by Mr P Lavery that Mr T Gregg be Elected and Proposed by Maj J Knowles and Seconded by Capt 
M Brennan that Mr R Kirkland be Elected.  These propositions were carried.  The Committee now consists of: 
 
Maj WE Matthews – Chairman 
WO2 (RQMS) K Gannaway-Pitts  
Mr D O’Leary 
Mr O Rice 
Capt A Gardner 
Lt Col J Faloone 
Capt M Brennan 
Maj J Quinn 
Mr T Gregg 
Mr R Kirkland 
Mr D Hyde – Hon Secretary & Treasurer 
 
CHAIRMANS POINTS 
 
7. The Chairman then gave his views on the wider use of Email for corresponding on Club, Regimental 
and other matters.  He encouraged those with Email to access the Regimental Web Page on the Internet and 
forward there Email address to himself, the Honorary Secretary and RQMS at Regimental Headquarters.  He 
also reminded Members of the importance of informing any change of address. 
 
ANY OTHER BUSINESS 
 
8. RSM Wilmont then issued an open invitation to all Members to call in at Knellar Hall if they were ever 
in the area.  This was warmly welcomed. 
 
9. There being no further business to discuss the Chairman Closed the Meeting at 1840 hours. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
         D B HYDE 
         Honorary Secretary & Treasurer
Honorary Secretary & Treasurer

				You are in:

					
	
					Surface Fleet
		Assault Ships
		Albion Class 
		HMS Bulwark
		Sports & Adventurous Training 

				
	


								

				

								

			
					
					
					
	Sports & Adventurous Training




Charity Football Match

HMS Bulwark?s football team featured for the first time in a football match against the Barrow Community Gym.  The game played on AFC Barrow?s pitch in the centre of the town also gave the ship an opportunity to raise much needed funds for the Gym which provides a facility to provide exercise therapy for people who suffer from mental health problems and related issues.  





Although beaten 3-0 Bulwark?s team put up a good performance and raised ?150 for the Gym to buy training equipment and support the general maintenance of the facility.

























Keswick to Barrow Sponsored Walk

On Saturday 8th May eight members of the ship?s company and three support drivers took part in the 38th Keswick to Barrow Sponsored Walk ? a distance of 40 miles. It was an early and damp start for the team who had to be registered along with the other 1000 walkers by 0600.  First home from the HMS Bulwark team was MAA David Harris who ran the course and finished in just over 8 Hours.  The fastest competitor completed the course in less than 5 hours!  The entire Bulwark team members completed the course and raised approximately ?500 for the ship?s charities. The Bulwark team were joined in the event by four members of the medical staff from the ship?s adopted hospital in Bishop Auckland who were very useful in treating the many blisters acquired by the walkers!



The Toughest Footrace On Earth

Captain Andy Ward, the Officer Commanding the Landing Craft Troop on board HMS Bulwark was one of two Royal Marines who took part in the Marathon des Sables, billed as the ?Toughest Footrace on Earth?.  The annual event is a 152 mile staged footrace held over 6 days in Southern Morocco over the period 11 ? 17 April.  The race is divided into daily stages of between 11 and 50 miles across a variety of terrain (rocky, gravel, pebbles and of course sand!) which start at 0900 daily to ensure that racing takes place over the hottest part of the day, temperatures at times hovering around the 45 degrees Centigrade mark.  The most difficult part of the race for Captain Ward and his Royal Marine colleague Major Trit Leydon was a 36Km stage including 18km over sand dunes followed the next day by the longest stage of 50 miles.  Both Royal Marine officers finished in the top third of the 600 international competitors.

title: Bank of England 2000 Press Release
text:
Bank of England 2000 Press Release 
	 	 
			 	 		 
	 
	 		 
	 
	 	

					 2001 News Releases	 
	
					  
	 	

					 2000 News Releases	 
	
					  
	 	1999

	 	Publications Main Page	 
	
					  
	 		 
	
					  
	 		 
	
					  
	 		 
	
					  
	 		 
	
					  

 	 
			 	
 
					 Speech by Ian Plenderleith, Member of the
						Monetary Policy Committee
 
					 14 June 2000 
 
					 In a speech today
						in the Midlands to the Stafford Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Ian
						Plenderleith, an Executive Director of the Bank of England and a member of the
						Monetary Policy Committee, was optimistic about the prospects for continued
						growth in the UK economy: 
 
					 "There are now some signs that the pace of activity
						may be moderating to a more sustainable level. Growth overall in the year to
						the first quarter was running at around 3% a year, still somewhat above
						long-run trend. Inflation is currently running somewhat below our target of
						2.5%. But cost pressures are still evident, particularly in the labour market,
						and may be reinforced if the exchange rate continues to ease, as it has in the
						past month. We need to remain vigilant, but, provided we take no risks with the
						progress we have made in recent years in maintaining low inflation, the
						prospect is for continuing growth overall on a basis that can be sustained into
						the medium term." 
 
					 Mr Plenderleith stressed the importance of maintaining low
						inflation: 
 
					 "Our first, and continuing, priority has to be to
						continue to deliver the stable monetary framework - of interest rates directed
						at maintaining low inflation - as a platform on which commerce and industry
						throughout the country can build their businesses and generate the growth in
						output and employment the country needs if we are to prosper on a continuing
						and sustained basis." 
 
					 However he recognised the unwelcome strains caused by the
						strength of sterling, and noted the dilemma this posed for the MPC: 
 
					 "… the effects have fallen most acutely on the
						manufacturing sector. The frustration felt by those who have built up efficient
						and competitive businesses, only to find their market position threatened by a
						rise in the exchange rate over which they have no control, is entirely
						understandable." 
 
					 "In judging how far, and how fast, to moderate
						domestic demand, we have taken into account the weakness of the UK's external
						sector, and the impact particularly on manufacturing, as an immediate factor
						offsetting in part the buoyancy of domestic demand. But we have also had to
						take into account the possibility further ahead that, if the exchange rate
						moves back to more realistic levels, as we expect, the boost that could bring
						to external demand could only be accommodated, without strains on the supply
						capacity of the economy as a whole, if domestic demand has moderated."
						
 
					 But he suggested that the exchange rate strains may now be
						abating with the recent recovery in the euro: 
 
					 "…it is reasonable to expect that the euro may
						in due course move back to more realistic levels; and that does indeed appear
						to have been happening in some part over the past month. Whether that will
						continue is hard to judge, but there are reasonable grounds for believing that
						some of the more extreme strains we have been experiencing from exchange rate
						movements may be abating." 
 
					 He touched on another, more positive, dilemma faced by the
						MPC, the ‘new economy’. Mr Plenderleith noted: 
 
					 "The reason why these advances, if they are
						translated into actual improvements in our economic performance, are so
						exciting is that they represent scope for improvements in the supply side of
						the economy: they hold out the possibility that the economy might be able to
						grow faster than recent historical experience without jeopardising price
						stability." 
 
					 But added that caution was important here: 
 
					 "…it will be extremely important that we do
						not anticipate the process and begin to award ourselves the benefits before we
						have seen concrete evidence that they have been captured in improved economic
						performance." 
 
					 Mr Plenderleith concluded: 
 
					 “The job of the MPC is to deliver a platform of
						continuing price stability so that business and industry across the country can
						continue to deliver the goods and services the market place wants.”
Bank of England 2000 Press Release

title: Bank of England 2004 Press Release - The UK Foreign Exchange andOver-the-Counter Derivatives Markets in April 2004, 28 September 2004
text:
Bank of England 2004 Press Release - The UK Foreign Exchange and
		Over-the-Counter Derivatives Markets in April 2004, 28 September 2004 
	 	 
			 	 		 
	 
	 		 
	 
	 	Summary of 2004 UK Survey
					 Results
(pdf file size 178k)	 
	
					  
	 	BIS 2004 Preliminary
					 Global Results	 
	
					  
	 	Survey of Foreign Exchange and OTC
					 Derivatives Activity Main Page	 
	
					  
	 	News Releases Main Page 	 
	
					  
	 		 
	
					  
	 		 
	
					  
	 		 
	
					  
	 		 
	
					  
	 		 
	
					  
	 		 
	
					  
	 		 
	
					  
	 		 
	
					  

 	 
			 	
 
					 News Release -
 The UK Foreign Exchange
						and Over-the-Counter Derivatives Markets in April 2004
 
					 28 September 2004
 
					  (Print friendly pdf
						version) 

					 In April this year, central banks and monetary authorities
						in 52 countries, including the UK, conducted the latest three-yearly survey of
						turnover in the markets for foreign exchange (spot, forwards and foreign
						exchange swaps) and over-the-counter (OTC) currency and interest rate
						derivatives. The surveys are co-ordinated on a global basis by the Bank for
						International Settlements (BIS), with the aim of obtaining comprehensive and
						internationally consistent information on the size and structure of the
						corresponding global markets. The Bank of England conducted the UK survey,
						which covers the business of institutions operating within the UK in these
						markets.
 
					 Foreign exchange market turnover in the UK increased by 49%
						from April 2001 to April 2004. The volume of OTC currency and interest rate
						derivatives business more than doubled over the same period. The UK remains the
						single largest centre of foreign exchange activity with 31.3% of global
						turnover in April 2004: this share is broadly unchanged since the previous
						survey.

					 The main findings of the UK survey are:
 
					 	Average daily turnover in foreign exchange was $753
						  billion during April 2004, 49% higher than the $504 billion per day
						  recorded for April 2001, or a rise of 30% at constant 2004 exchange rates. This
						  growth has returned the level of turnover to beyond that seen during April
						  1998, more than offsetting the fall in turnover between April 1998 and April
						  2001. 
	The largest percentage growth between 2001 and 2004 was
						  in outright forward transactions, (94%), followed by spot (47%) and swap
						  transactions (43%). Outright forward trades now account for 14% of total UK
						  foreign exchange activity, compared with 11% in 2001.
	Electronic trading accounts for 55% of total foreign
						  exchange activity, and 67% of inter-dealer spot business (of which the majority
						  is via automated order-matching systems).
	 Average daily turnover in OTC currency and interest
						  rate derivatives was $643 billion during April 2004, compared with the $275
						  billion recorded for April 2001.
	The growth within OTC currency and interest rate
						  derivatives was most pronounced in the OTC interest rate option market, which
						  saw turnover increase from $13 billion in April 2001 to $94 billion in April
						  2004, and now accounts for 15% of the overall OTC currency and interest rate
						  derivatives market.

 
					 The December 2004 issue of the Bank of England Quarterly
						Bulletin will provide further analysis and more comprehensive statistics
						for the UK.

					 The BIS is publishing preliminary global results today (see
						the BIS
						website), with a detailed analysis to follow early in 2005. Central banks
						of many other countries are also publishing their own survey results; links to
						their websites can be found on the BIS website.
 
					 Notes to Editors
 
					 A total of 93 institutions, mainly commercial and investment
						banks, participated in the UK survey. This was fewer than in previous surveys
						(for example, there were 253 participants in 2001), as only firms that
						participate in the inter-dealer market and/or have an active business with
						large customers were asked to complete the 2004 survey. Others active in the UK
						market were not directly involved in the survey, but their transactions with
						participating principals will have been recorded by those institutions.
 
					 For the twenty business days in April 2004, participants
						were asked to provide details of their gross turnover in each market, broken
						down in terms of specified categories of currency, transaction and
						counterparty. Gross turnover (measured in nominal values) is defined as the
						absolute total value of all deals entered into during the month - i.e. there is
						no netting of purchases against sales. Data were requested in terms of US
						dollar equivalents, rounded to the nearest million. 

					 The basis of reporting was the location of the sales desk of
						the trade. This is a change from the 2001 survey where location was defined by
						the location of the price-setting dealer. 
 
					 Turnover figures are published on a net basis. In the UK an
						adjustment is made for the fact that trades between participants in the UK
						survey will have been reported by both parties to the transaction; other
						countries have also adjusted their data in this way. The BIS have, in addition,
						adjusted the global data for cross-border double counting prior to publication
						today. Aggregating published national results would overstate global turnover
						due to cross-border double counting.
Bank of England 2004 Press Release - The UK Foreign Exchange andOver-the-Counter Derivatives Markets in April 2004, 28 September 2004

The Delivery and Reform Group
The Cabinet Office is home to a number of units, each with a distinct role, but each contributing to the overall aim of delivery and reform. They report to the Cabinet Secretary, Sir Andrew Turnbull.
The Strategy Unit
The Strategy Unit's aim is to improve Government's capacity to address strategic, cross-cutting issues and promote innovation in the development of policy and the delivery of the Government's objectives.
The unit was set up in 2002, bringing together the Performance and Innovation Unit (PIU), the Prime Minister's Forward Strategy Unit (FSU), and parts of the Centre for Management and Policy Studies (CMPS).
The unit has four main roles:
	undertaking long-term strategic reviews of major areas of policy;
	undertaking studies of cross-cutting policy issues;
	strategic audit (occasional assessments of how well the UK, and UK government are doing); and
	working with departments to promote strategic thinking and improve policy making across Whitehall.

The Prime Minister's Delivery Unit
The Delivery Unit is headed by Michael Barber and is responsible for ensuring that the Government achieves its delivery priorities, both across the key areas of public service (health, education, crime, asylum and transport) and in the other main domestic service delivery departments. Working closely with the Treasury, the Unit ensures that the departments have in place effective delivery plans for their Public Service Agreements and develops the framework, methodology and database for delivering these targets and identify training and development needs for civil servants involved.
The Delivery Unit reports regularly to the Prime Minister through the Minister for the Cabinet Office on progress on the delivery priorities of the delivery departments. It establishes the agenda for his regular stocktake meetings with the Ministers concerned; and also reports twice a year to the PSX Cabinet Committee. All departments remain accountable for meeting their PSAs through the PSX process.
The Office of Public Service Reform
The OPSR is headed by Wendy Thomson and focuses on reform of public services, such as the NHS, schools, police and local government. It has responsibility for:
	Communicating the principles and values of public service reform and customer focus to the wider public service, and identifying and promoting best practice.
	Models for improving public service delivery by working with departments on more flexible structures, systems, processes, and ways of involving the private and voluntary sectors.
	Pay and recruitment problems in the public sector.
	Developing systems for managing cross-cutting issues affecting service delivery, and improving links between departments and the wider public sector, including the use of e-Technology.
	Devising improved methods of public service management that reduce the impact of regulation on front-line services, working with departments and the Public Sector Team of the Regulatory Impact Unit.

Corporate Development Group
Headed by Alice Perkins, this group spearheads the work on bringing in more talent, developing it better and raising the capability of Human Resource management throughout Whitehall. The component parts are:
	Talent: covering recruitment, career development, diversity, interchange and succession planning.
	Leadership Development and Skills: identifying the training and development needed in the Civil Service, and commissioning it.
	Pay and Performance: developing pay, performance management and pensions systems and flexible retirement arrangements that support our wider objectives.
	Modern People Management: making the way we manage people throughout Whitehall, in HR departments and in the line, more professional
	The Centre for Management and Policy Studies, incorporating the Civil Service College, is a key provider and enabler of training and development, working with a range of outside institutions.

e-Government Unit
The e-Government Unit works with departments to deliver efficiency savings while improving the delivery of public services by joining up electronic government services around the needs of customers.
The e-Government Unit's responsibilities include:
	strategy: developing policy and planning for ICT within Government;
	architecture: providing policy, design, standards, governance, advice and guidance for ICT in Central Government;
	innovation: providing high-level advice to Government bodies on innovative opportunities arising from ICT to improve efficiency;
	IT Finance: in partnership with OGC, monitoring major IT projects in Government and advising on major investment decisions (in partnership with OGC);
	IT HR: Head of the IT Profession in Government and leading its professional development;
	research: identifying and communicating key technology trends, opportunities, threats and risks for Government;
	supplier Management: in partnership with OGC, managing the top-level relationship with strategic suppliers to Government (in partnership with OGC).

The e-Government Unit / CSIA also provides sponsorship of Information Assurance.
The Reform Strategy Team
The team is headed by Paul Kirby and has responsibility for:
	defining the overall Civil Service reform strategy
	developing the Departmental Change Programme
	supporting the Civil Service Management Board
	communicating the reform message through the Civil Service
	The Office of Government Commerce

The Office of Government Commerce
The Office of Government Commerce is part of the Treasury and is responsible for a wide-ranging programme to modernise procurement in government, and deliver substantial value for money improvements. The OGC's Chief Executive, Peter Gershon, is also a member of the Delivery and Reform Group with the remit of helping to improve the capability of the civil service to commission and deliver major projects. The OGC also works on training civil servants in project management skills and on developing tools to improve the management of projects.

					Fleet Air Arm
		Naval Air Squadrons
		845
		About us

				
	


								

				

								

			
					
					
					
	About us



The Squadron is very much a team, with every member vital to the smooth operation and capability. Being sailors we are at home on board a warship but are also trained in military skills and can live and fight in the field - in any environment. Trades include:

 

Pilots and Aircrewmen form the crew of the aircraft. The Aircrewmen assist in all aspects of aviation, whilst carrying out cabin duties such as loading troops or equipment, and monitoring underslung loads. 



Engineer Officers run all aspects of aircraft maintenance. Articifers are the Royal Navy's technicians, specialists with an in-depth knowledge of the aircraft systems and fault diagnosis.

 

Air Engineering Mechanics are responsible for routine maintenance and fault rectification.

 

Aircraft Handlers not only have the driving skills for tractor-towing aircraft on a moving deck in a force 9 wind, but are the Royal Navy's specialist fire-fighters on board aircraft carriers and at Air Stations.

 

Cooks and Stewards provide support on board ships and also in our permanent detachments such as Bosnia. They will also set up field kitchens when the Squadron deploys for long periods in the field. 

Writers provide the administration support necessary for running a multi-million pound organisation with over 200 personnel. 845 Sqn also has its own fully trained Medical Assistants.

 

Royal Marines also make an important contribution to the Squadron bringing the benefit of advanced tactical knowledge and military skills. They serve in a number of roles,- 

·	Aircrewmen. 

·	Mobile Air Operations Teams - providing signalling and load-rigging skills. 

·	Platoon Weapons Instructors - advising on weapons and tactical skills. 

·	Motor Transport Drivers and Mechanics - maintaining the Squadron's fleet of Land Rovers.

  Quality and choice: a decent home for all: The Housing Green Paper - Responses








	
	
	
		
		
		
	
	
		
	


        








     






			
			
			
                        








 

			
	
	
	
		
	
		
	
	

			
				
				

			
			
			
                        








 

			
	
	
	
		
	
		
	
	

			
				
				
	


       















	
	
	
	
	
		
	

	
	
	
	
	
			
	


	
	
	
	Other Formats: 
	 833 Kb 
	
 691 Kb  Download help












	
	
		
			
		
		


	 





7. Raising The Quality Of Social Housing


Chapter 7 of the Housing Green Paper 'Raising the quality of social housing' covers the following issues:


  	 Encouraging more local authorities to consider the benefits of stock transfer;
	 Supporting the transfer of up to 200,000 homes each year;
	 Providing more detailed stock transfer guidance for local authorities;
	 Enabling a transfer programme to extend over two financial years;
	 Consultation on changes to the LSVT levy for the 2001 transfer programme;
	 Introducing new Stamp Duty relief for registered social landlords;
	 Conducting a review to consider further improvements to the transfer process;
	 Introduce arms length management companies;
	 Pilot the PFI for housing and consider future levels of support;
	 Implement Best Value for Housing;
	 Follow up recommendations of PAT5 and PAT7 on housing management;
	 Ensure improvements through the Housing Inspectorate;
	 Develop Best Value and Tenant Participation guidance for registered social landlords;
	 Work up Housing Corporation proposals to support different types of resident control;
	 Adapt the Housing Corporations regulatory framework to promote further efficiencies;
	 Consider levels of investment in future years; and
	 Introduce a new financial regime for local authorities.




	Figure 9Comments on 'Raising the quality of social housing'


	





415 respondents comment on Chapter 7 of the Housing Green Paper. Figure 9 shows the type of respondents commenting. 181 local authorities and 77 registered social landlords comment. Towards the lower end of the scale Individual respondents make up three per cent, Academics or Professionals make up two per cent and Councillors or MPs make up 1 per cent of those responding to the proposals on raising the quality of social housing.Figure 10 depicts the region that the respondent represents when commenting on raising the standard of social housing, 19 per cent are based in London, 14 per cent are based in the South East and 11 per cent are national representative agencies. The region with the least number of responses is Merseyside, which makes up 2 per cent of the total. However, as the total number of respondents to any aspect of the Green Paper is 13, the number responding on issues within Chapter 7 account for 54 per cent of all respondents from Merseyside.



	Figure 10Comments on 'Raising the quality of social housing' by Region


	






	Summary of views on 'Raising the quality of social housing

1. 415 respondents comment on Chapter 7 'Raising the quality of social housing'. This represents 38 per cent of all respondents to the Housing Green Paper.

2. Respondents are more likely to have concerns about the stock transfer process than support it. Fifty three per cent of the 261 respondents who explicitly comment on whether they support the stock transfer programme, express concern. The remaining 47 per cent actively support the programme.

3. Only 17 respondents actively state support for the increase in the stock transfer programme to 200,000 homes per year.

4. There is slightly more concern about the criteria of stock transfer, and the inclusion of an element of competition between new social landlords, than support for the criteria. Twenty five respondents have concerns compared to 14 respondents who support the criteria.

5. Every respondents commenting on the extension of the stock transfer programme to 2 years are supportive (20 respondents comment on this proposal)

6. Just over a fifth of respondents (21 per cent of those commenting on Chapter 7) share the view that stock transfer should be considered as one of a menu of options available to a local authority and its tenants to improve the condition of the stock.

7. Almost half of respondents (49 per cent) state that local discretion is paramount and that tenant involvement is critical.

8. Just under half (43 per cent) of the respondents comment on arms length companies, of whom 80 per cent are supportive of the proposals.

9. A quarter (24 per cent) want to see the detail of arms length companies developed more.

10. There is a broad welcome for the government's recognition of the size of the repairs backlog by 29 per cent of respondents. Increased funding is welcomed.

11. Twenty one per cent of respondents to Chapter 7 want to see the discussion on local authority access to funding reviewed, to put authorities onto a level playing field with registered social landlords.





7.1 The stock transfer programme


Support for stock transfer


The Green Paper states the Government's intention to encourage more local authorities to consider the benefits of transfer both from a housing perspective and wider economic and social regeneration. Respondents are more likely to have concerns about the stock transfer process than support it. Fifty three per cent of the 261 respondents who explicitly comment on whether they support the stock transfer programme, express concern. The remaining 47 per cent actively support the programme.


Forty per cent of those agreeing are registered social landlords with 23 per cent being local authorities. Two are tenants groups with the rest being representative bodies such as the Commission for Racial Equality and the Chartered Institute of Housing.


Fewer respondents comment on the detail of the proposed stock transfer programme, and where they do the level of support is often mixed. For example only 17 respondents actively state support for the increase in the stock transfer programme to 200,000 homes per year. 


Every respondents commenting on the extension of the stock transfer programme to 2 years are supportive (20 respondents comment on this proposal) and 14 per cent would welcome further improvements to the stock transfer process. The latter group of respondents often suggested improvements, such as a stronger monitoring role for the local authority once the stock transfer has taken place, an option to transfer the stock back to the local authority where the new social landlord does not perform well, and a more active role for tenants in the decision making process.


Concerns with the stock transfer programme


Leaving the issue of who explicitly commented on supporting or disagreeing with stock transfer, a range of other comments are made. Concerns are voiced by 32 per cent of all respondents to Chapter 7. Of those expressing a concern two thirds make the point that stock transfer is just one option and it needs to be taken into consideration that tenants might choose to stay with the local authority. Tied to this is the issue of local democracy in that it is up to the tenants to decide whether to transfer. Half of the respondents think that local discretion and tenant choice is important when a local authority considers whether or not to transfer its stock. Forty five per cent of these respondents are local authorities. There is no significant regional variation to this response.


What should happen if tenants decide not to transfer is debated by a number of local authorities. One view that sums up this is issue is that:


'It is considered that in situations where tenants have not supported a transfer, or where an option appraisal has not identified any benefits for such a transfer, that the local authority should not be penalised through capital or revenue funding restrictions and thus be prevented from performing to the best of its ability.' (Tendring District Council)


A few more local authorities and an MP expand on this point by asking what is so wrong about council housing that local authorities should be encouraged to transfer their stock.


Related to this is a concern from some registered social landlords about the difficulties existing registered social landlords have 'breaking in to the local authority market.' By this it is meant that many LSVT registered social landlords are those set up by the local authority to receive the stock and existing registered social landlords are by and large excluded from the process.


In developing this point further one registered social landlord is particularly concerned about how the flow of information coming from the local authority in the pre ballot stage is often designed to achieve the result the authority desired. They state:


'Put simply we do not believe that the appropriate information will be provided and that most tenants will continue to be persuaded to vote in favour of transfer associations promoted by the local authority.' (Hyde Housing Association)


Transferring up to 200,000 homes each year


The proposal to support up to 200,000 received very few comments. Seventeen respondents explicitly support the proposals while a further 15 express concern.


Concerns centre on a number of issues. These can be summarised as:


  	 Whether the proposed 12,000 dwelling limit is of sufficient size to give economies of scale;
	 Whether there are potential Board members of sufficient calibre to make sit on the board; and 
	 Whether the proposed transfer programme will in fact create a registered social landlord based monopoly.



The argument about economies of scale is centred on current practice within the registered social landlord sector towards mergers and group structures. It is felt that the 12,000 limit conflicts with the move towards bigger more efficient registered social landlords. Interestingly a tenants group also call for the 12,000 limit to be increased but for the very different reason that the smaller level would split up the estate and mean that tenants could get a different level of service from different landlords on the same estate.


Stock transfer criteria


The Green Paper sets out the key criteria by which proposals for transfer will be considered and states further that the evaluation by a local authority on whether to transfer should be firmly grounded in the principles of Best Value. There is slightly more concern about the criteria of stock transfer, and the inclusion of an element of competition between new social landlords, than support for the criteria. Twenty five respondents have concerns compared to 14 respondents who support the criteria.


They main concern expressed relates to the element of competition proposed between registered social landlords, with some respondents seeing this as divisive.


Extending the transfer programme over two financial years


The government believe that the requirement to complete the transfer within one financial year acts as a constraint against further stock transfer. The Green Paper proposes, therefore, that transfers can be extended over two financial years. Twenty respondents, predominantly registered social landlords or local authorities that have gone through a stock transfer explicitly state their agreement with the proposed two year extension.


The LSVT levy 


The government does not propose to change the flat rate levy of 20 per cent on capital receipts arising from the sale of stock. The levy on preserved Right to Buy properties was scrapped on 1st April 1999. Seventeen respondents make reference to the levy with eight agreeing with the proposals and nine disagreeing.


Stamp Duty Relief


Only 10 respondents make reference to Stamp Duty, and all agree with the proposal and the listed exemptions.


Reviewing the stock transfer process


Fourteen per cent of respondents comment on the proposed review of the stock transfer process by suggesting improvements. Of those suggesting improvements one third are registered social landlords and a further quarter are local authorities. A number of suggested improvements are made including:


  	 Improving the information available to tenants;
	 Allowing greater flexibility in the size of transfers (the 12,000 limit);
	 Putting all options available to a local authority (and its tenants) on an equal basis;
	 Greater utilisation of existing registered social landlords and group structures to facilitate transfer; and 
	 Avoiding a two tier system.



About 12 per cent of all respondents to this chapter suggest that transfer should be monitored on a long term basis to make sure that transfer are achieving real and measurable benefit. Among those making this comment are The Peabody Trust and the London Boroughs of Barnet, Greenwich and Islington and the Housing Corporation.Other respondents make the link between the rent restructuring proposals and proposals relating to the transfer programme and think that there is a contradiction in policy that needs to be reviewed. The argument is that the transfer programme could be stalled if LSVT registered social landlords have to adhere to RPI only rent increases, because it would make the business plan unviable (see Chapter 10).


Monopoly landlords


Fourteen per cent of respondents commenting on Chapter 7 warn against the advent of monopoly registered social landlord providers. Commentators include registered social landlords. This it is stated would not be good for tenants. 


'The creation of more LSVT landlords may well lead to less consumer choice, and less efficiency as the new RSLs swamp existing players in the market, duplicate service provision and contribute to overheating in the local market for housing staff.' (Knightstone Housing Association)


The Audit Commission develops this view further and recognises that there could be conflicting aims:


'There is clear tension between the need to increase competition and prevent large scale monopolies on one hand and the need to secure economies of scale in procurement and service delivery.' (The Audit Commission)


The Audit Commission, along with other respondents (South Tyneside Metropolitan Borough Council for example), warn against a 'two tier' system of stock improvement for local authorities where those that are 'excellent' go for the arms length company option and the LSVT route becomes 'second best.'


7.2 Arms length companies


The Housing Green Paper gives local authorities the option of setting up arms length companies to manage its stock while retaining ownership. The Green Paper points out that a key feature of the initiative will be the ability to use more rental income to finance borrowing for investment in stock improvement. Only a small number of local authorities would be able to pursue this option and only those authorities that have demonstrated a high level of performance against Best Value targets, have demonstrated sound financial planning and provided a clear plan on rent restructuring will be considered.


Just under half (43 per cent) of the respondents comment on arms length companies, of whom 80 per cent are supportive of the proposals. Nearly three quarters of which are local authorities and half of these are in London and the South East. Many of those welcoming the proposal state that the option will give local authorities and their tenants more choice in the future management of the stock.


A number of observations and concerns are expressed and a quarter (24 per cent) want to see the detail of arms length companies developed more. Leicester City Council state that it will be important that extra funding for arms length companies is guaranteed, even if performance falls below performance standards. They advocate funding for a minimum of five years.


Twenty one per cent of respondents to Chapter 7 express a view on whether the criteria for selection of arms length companies should include the criteria that only high performing local authorities should be able to create an arms length company. Of those commenting 86 per cent have concerns about limiting opportunities to high performing landlords only. One of the key arguments is that the decision of future ownership should be a local decision involving tenants and the local authority and that if it is decided that this is the best option then they should be allowed to pursue it. Others are concerned about how the 'high performers' are to be defined.


10 per cent of all respondents comment that arms length companies should be created on a par with the stock transfer programme, in terms of size of properties included in the yearly programme, in terms of accessing private finance, and in terms of how tenant are involved. Respondents recognise that a ballot is a sensible way to gather opinion from tenants on whether they want to proceed with an arms length company. The issue of public accountability is also raised, which has been considered in Chapter 2 of this report.


An argument against arms length companies centred on local democratic control.


'The creation of an arms length company will inevitably result in the loss or reduction of local democratic control over the management of council assets. The close relationship between local councillors and tenant representatives has been a keystone in achieving housing management practices which has led the council to be rated 'well above average' and also the awarding of three Charter Marks for Housing Management.' (Ipswich Borough Council)


Clarification is needed on the arms length proposal. The Abbey National point out that the Green Paper is sending out mixed messages about the ownership of social housing stock, and that clarity is needed, otherwise lenders may be reluctant to lend to registered social landlords. Their concern is that the Government appear to state that the best performing landlords will opt for arms length companies, with the second best option being stock transfer. This mentality will not please private financiers of stock transfer.


7.3 The Private Finance Initiative (PFI)


An option for local authorities is the Private Finance Initiative (PFI). Under the PFI local authorities enter into long term service contracts with the private sector to provide refurbishment, management, maintenance or repairs services. Providing the private sector takes a significant share of the risk, investment is not subject to public expenditure controls.


Use of the PFI attracted comment from 18 per cent of respondents. Of these, three quarters agree with the principle of PFI. Ten respondents ask for more clarity on how extra capital resources for PFI are to be funded. Twenty one respondents state that it is important that tenants are involved in any discussion of future ownership or funding options. Five of these are tenant organisations.


A few respondents express caution in the use of PFI until the results from the pilot authorities have been evaluated.


Registered social landlord board members


The issue of the calibre of RSL board members is mentioned by a few registered social landlords that are active in receiving local authority stock. These associations have noticed that it is becoming increasingly more difficult to attract people onto Boards. It is felt that this shortage could undermine the success of the LSVT programme in certain areas. Other registered social landlords point to skills shortages in housing management staff that again act as a constraint to transfer.


In response to this argument, however, Moat Housing Group state:


'Greater use of existing housing association group structures for housing transfer may help overcome the potential skills shortages of staff and Board members.'


With respondent commitment to greater involvement of tenants in the future of their housing stock, regardless of the form of ownership, the issue of representative board members will become increasingly apparent in the future.


7.4 Best Value and Tenant Participation Compacts


There is strong support for the principles of Best Value within the overall context of funding decisions. One quarter of respondents explicitly make reference to Best Value. These are a mix of registered social landlords, local authorities, tenant groups and national representative agencies.


A similar proportion of respondents (and a similar mix of type) agree with the need to frame consultation within the Tenant Participation Compact structure.


Seventeen per cent of respondents explicitly stated that they agree that registered social landlords should be subject to an inspection process similar to that used under Best Value for local authorities. One third of those agreeing are registered social landlords and a further third are local authorities. Others agreeing include the Federation of Black Housing Organisations, The Institute for Public Policy Research and the National Housing Federation.


A small number of respondents (21) state that they welcome further guidance from the Housing Corporation on Best Value and Tenant Participation Compacts.


Many respondents (15 per cent of all responses) make reference to the need to involve tenants more generally in decision making, whether that be related to stock transfer, more general elements of service delivery or resident control of estates. Many respondents point to what they see as existing good practice and think that there is more that others could do.


All of these respondents see benefits in involving tenants more directly in both provision of services and in managing their estates.


A small number of respondents comment on the need to adapt the Housing Corporation's regulatory framework to promote further efficiencies in management and responsive to tenants by registered social landlords. Eight respondents welcome the adaptation. 


7.5 Recommendations from Policy Action Teams' 5 and 7


Twenty four respondents explicitly endorse the findings of Policy Action Team (PAT) 5 and PAT 7 and welcome the increased resources for housing management and on the spot housing management techniques.However, many more respondents (133 in total) raise the general issue of the need to link proposals in the Housing green Paper with recommendations stemming from other policies on regeneration, low demand and social exclusion, including the National Strategy for Neighbourhood Renewal which encompasses recommendations from the PATs (See Chapter 3).


7.6 Future investment


The reference in the Green Paper to reviewing the level of future investment in social housing particularly to fund the repair backlog received much comment. This area attracts comment from 30 per cent of respondents, two fifths of whom are local authorities. Respondents welcoming the review do so in the context of the government's own estimates of £19 billion repairs backlog. Many local authorities in their response also make reference to repairs backlog locally and how the gap between what is needed and what has been allocated in the past has widened. This is one area where the welcome is very much upbeat (one respondent saying it is a 'miraculous' admission by the government).


7.7 New financial regime for local authority housing


The proposed changes to local authority Housing Revenue Accounts (HRA) have been subject to a separate consultation exercise and very few respondents make comments within their response to the Housing Green Paper. Of those that did, 12 welcome the change but eight express concerns mainly centred on the specific aspects of the HRA changes.


7.8 Ideas suggested


Respondents raise other ideas that could be considered in the development of the proposals, including:


  	 Local authorities should be able to sell homes more freely and keep the capital receipts;
	 Local authorities should be able to access finance on the same basis as registered social landlords.




	Key links to Chapter 7

Creating a level playing field; tenure neutrality; Tenant Choice; long term planning; linking with the wider context; Making it work locally, the Challenges ahead.












		




	










	
		
		See also:

			Quality and choice: a decent home for all: The Housing Green Paper 
	The Housing Policy Statement and The Housing Green Paper

title: Foreign & Commonwealth Office Jack Straw latest statements
text:
Foreign & Commonwealth Office Jack Straw latest statements

















Back to Full Graphics






















UN REPORT ON SUDAN: STRAW WELCOMES LIMITED IMPROVEMENT


(01/09/04)









The Foreign Secretary, Jack Straw, today issued an initial response to the UN report on Sudan.  He said:

  

'I welcome the UN report released today.  The report confirms what I saw first hand during my visit to Darfur last week and is in line with my discussion with Mr Pronk in Khartoum.  There has been some progress in Sudan over the past 30 days, including improvements in the humanitarian situation and limited disarmament of the Popular Defence Force.  But we need to see much more.'



'The Government of Sudan is still not doing enough to disarm the militias.  A culture of impunity continues, with no evidence that the perpetrators of these appalling attacks are being brought to justice.'



'I believe that the modest improvements to date have come about primarily because of the pressure exerted by the international community.'

  

'We will now want to listen to the Special Representative's presentation to the Security Council, and discuss his recommendations urgently with Security Council partners.'





Sudan Country Profile

The United Kingdom in the United Nations

title: Plaid Cymru - The Party of Wales - PlaidCymru.org Press Release
text:
Plaid Cymru - The Party of Wales - PlaidCymru.org Press Release














Mai 12fed.....May 12th 2004





	

Plaid demands better funding for mental health sector

	




Plaid Cymru - Party of Wales AM Dai Lloyd raised the issue of funding for
mental health provision during Health question time in the Assembly today.


Speaking after a meeting with the Mental Health Alliance at the Assembly Dai Lloyd said:


"With Health being one of the government's top three priorities what is the
Welsh Assembly Government going to do about the increasing level of core
funding from the Assembly to enable more developments in mental health
supported housing?" 


He added:


"Much valuable work in supporting people with mental health problems living
in our communities is being done by local authorities and the voluntary
sector in Wales. Increased provision of much-needed supported housing for
people with mental health problems would happen with consistent core-funding
from the Welsh Assembly Government. The ball is the Health Ministers court."




Diwedd/Ends.
